content:
ber 13, 2015
The best laid schemes...Favorite quotes:"Yeah yeah, I get it.  'Let the Goblin do it; he's cute, but expendable!'" -Styx the Goblin."...you want me to calm things down?  That's not really one of my strong points." -Arkhail, Orc berserker.Of Orcs And Men by Spiders Studio/Cyanide Studio/Focus Home Interactive is problematic & at times unimpressive, but still something I'd recommend to single player fantasy action & RPG aficionados.  The game is saved by engaging story & characters as well as the unusual combat mechanics.First of all, combat.  Of the two player characters, Arkhail is a natural tank with taunts, stuns, area of effect & heavy hitting attacks.  Styx deals big damage & has useful debuffs at both melee & ranged distance.  There are a few "shared" utility skills requiring both characters.  The skills eventually make combat a little tedious, even though you can bind skills to number keys.  Pause feature is nifty, giving you time to think about which opponent to eliminate next.A quick word on the RPG progression elements: You'll level up, distribute attribute points into statistics like strength, agility, etcetera.  You'll also find, buy, sell, & upgrade equipment with varying stats.  I tended towards Agility for Styx & Stamina or Defense for Arkhail.  This mostly worked well.  Bear in mind however that there will be times when you're forced to rely on one or the other alone, so try to keep them a bit more self sufficient than I did!As for strategy, I tend to travel using Styx, open combat from stealth, then switch to Arkhail and hold aggro.  Certain units are strong against either Styx or Arkhail; be sure to learn & exploit enemy weaknesses (it's not obvious).  Be mindful of patrols & time your assassinations to cull a group as much as possible before open combat.Friendly AI isn't always helpful; absent your input, the non-controlled player character will default to the basic attack or even at times delay before doing anything.  In these cases you have to switch back & forth manually giving orders to both.  Targeting is another issue: it doesn't always stick, so you have to retarget the desired enemy; particularly annoying is that your movement is locked at times due to the AI carrying out your orders, which means you can't quickly move Styx out of harm's way without pausing, clearing his action queue, and re-engaging.Stealth mechanics also leave something to be desired, and even at times feel immersion breaking although that's arguably nitpicking.  While in stealth, Styx has a maximum range of movement away from Arkhail (can't leave the big guy behind!) so be sure to park Arkhail as close as you can without being detected, especially working a large area.  Stealth doesn't require disposal of slain enemies.  Enemy AI doesn't notice bodies at all; patrols walk right by bodies you just backstabbed without pause.  They also have impossibly narrow vision range & poor hearing, allowing you to kill baddies close by their friends (especially if you upgrade Styx for stealth).On difficulty settings & boss encounters: There are Easy, Medium, Hard & Extreme.  I went with Medium, & the antiheroic duo felt very powerful on this difficulty.  On the other hand, combat difficulty soars from low to very high transitioning from Medium to Hard or Extreme.  In my opinion it simply isn't fun or rewarding above Medium.  Frustratingly, two of the late/final combat encounters are absurdly difficult until you figure out the right tactics.  Making this worse is that choosing the wrong stats & skills can & will sabotage your ability to complete those fights as well as you could; like I said before, gear & upgrade your characters carefully.What really tops that cake and renders the entire thing a bit ridiculous is the poorly placed save points.  Coupled with your inability to save manually while in combat, this means for those tough fights you'll have to either redo most of an area to reach the boss combat, sit through a mountain of unskippable cutscene & dialogue before actually getting to play, or both.  I'm fine with having to retry a fight until I've learned how to succeed, but nobody wants to sit through the same content like that only to die in a poorly tuned combat encounter.The aforementioned design & balancing issues were enough to sour the experience for me a bit, in spite of my appreciation for the unique combat mechanics & my enjoyment of the story/characterization.  I know lots of players will be better than I and get through the game on Hard or Extreme but I can't imagine bothering with it.  I was ready to be done by the time I beat the game.I was underwhelmed by other aspects of Of Orcs And Men.  Level design is a bit simple, doesn't take much advantage of vertical space besides placing ranged enemies in unreachable perches.  You can use Styx's ranged stance to eliminate them, or the Goblin Toss ability.  Pathing and physics felt jumbled in certain areas.  Visuals were okay by 2012 standards when the game released.  Audio was acceptable, but unmemorable.  Thankfully there were no discernible bugs or technical issues.  The game ran well with settings maxed @ 1920/1080p.Story & characterization were clever.  It is solidly entertaining fantasy fiction fare with colorful main characters & a unique angle, showing the plight and perspective of orcs & goblins rather than humans, elves & dwarves.  Even this had pros & cons though.  Writing for much of the dialogue & cutscenes (there is a lot of both in the game) felt at times heavy handed, cheesy or just too drawn out.  Voice acting was passably good.All said & done, the reason I'm giving this a thumbs up recommendation is the creative treatment plus the modest amount of fun the combat offers.  I'm glad I played & learned the tale of Styx & Arkhail.  I would only recommend Of Orcs And Men if you've already tapped other, better fantasy fare & are interested in a slightly different take on the genre.  I'll eventually be trying out the 2014 sequel, Styx: Master of Shadows (which is apparently the prequel in terms of story).

content:
y 13, 2014
												I finished this a while back so this isn't as fresh in my memory as it should. Also I have to be honest here, cyanide games are a guilty pleasure of mine. I always think there are some good ideas floating in their games but they don't manage to make the best out of all those ideas. That being said on to the main event.Gameplay:You play as 2 characters here and you can switch between them at any time once you get the second one. The first is the orc, Arkhail, and the second is the goblin, Styx.Each of them has 3 skill trees in which you can add points to get new abilities or improve an ability in 1 of 2 different ways that adds an effect like stun or lifesteal to that ability . Arkhail has a berserker and a tank tree and the 3rd has some actions that include Styx like throwing him towards enemies and later on when you choose a specialization class(story event) you get some more skills here. Styx has an assassin tree and ranged dagger throwing tree and the 3rd again has combo actions such as throwing a heal potion to Arkhail. These skill trees/wheels also count as stances that give different bonuses.Speaking of potions there are none :P You have to keep your HP up by using skills, items with lifesteal and good planning before going into the fight.Both characters can equip gear that drops or is found in chests and is specific for each character. While there isn't a whole lot of gear each new item you find will be different and sometimes they will be sidegrades instead of upgrades so they can be useful to the build you are using for them.The fights can get rather challenging at times but all of them can be overcome with some good planning. The main thing to take into account is that Arkhail has a rage meter that can build up pretty fast and sends him into berserker mode where he is faster and stronger but you cannot control his actions and he sometimes takes pauses just to roar at the enemies in which time he gets pummeled. It's up to you if you want to go the berserker route and try to survive fights counting on his rage or go the tank way where you can control his rage and diminish with certain skills. Personally I went berserker for Arkhail and assassin for styx with a few skills from the other trees just enough to cover all my bases and it was fine though there were some fights that I had to restart quite a few times. It is by no means an easy game.Graphics:From a distance they graphics look OK but when the camera zooms in for conversations the textures are really bad and blurry. A high res texture pack would to wonders for the game but I doubt we'll ever see anything like that. There is variety in the locations you go as far as design but the overall color palette is pretty bland with a lot of browns and greys.Sound:I'm not really good at this part. Thesound seems ok to me but maybe someone with a better ear will tell you differently. The music is good and the volumes are well implemented (as opposed to viking battle of asgard). My only issue here is that half the voice actors are bad. Arkhail and Styx are ok though and it's their banter that you will be hearing for most of the game anyway.Story:At the beginning the human empire is waging a massive war against all greenskins and is winning. The chief of the clan tasks Arkhail with killing the emperor as to finish the war. Arkhail needs help getting to the emperor so a guide is hired and this is where Styx comes in. From there the story has all sorts of twists and turn, some that you will expect and others that you won't. I really enjoyed the story but what I enjoyed more was Styx. He's just one of those characters that you either love or hate and if you love him you can't get enough of him.Bottom line:While there could be improvements done to all sorts of things it was an enjoyable RPG that has replay value at least for the way you can customize the play style of the 2 characters. Also take note that a lot of F-bombs are dropped, and I mean a whole lot (just in case you wanna give this to your kids to play and you're worried about that sort of thing).

content:
, 2016
												The graphics/models/textures all looked pretty good. Not amazing but it’s 4 years old now. The setting/story is interesting. It puts you in the shoes of what is often thought of as the evil mindless villains. You get to see that they have their own motivations and are only mad because of the racism, slavery and cruelty they have suffered at the hands of man. This game is very story driven and one of the things I didn’t like about it is that you play for a couple minutes and then interrupted by a cut-scene sort of thing with dialogue and whatnot. Occasionally you have a little bit of choice on what you want to say, but rarely. Matt asked me at one point how I was liking it as I was about 25 minutes in and I said I had hardly played any yet because it’s all cut-scene. That doesn’t always bother me if it’s the right type of game, but I thought this was more action oriented. Oh well.Being a story driven game it should be really well written, and this one, I would say is okay. Not great. It has some jokes, some of which are REALLY crude! But at the same time it’s littered with modern language, particularly swearing, that just seems so jarring to me. I don’t need middle English thee and thou but it sure doesn’t feel like fantasy talk to me, when the language would fit today. So that is a bit of an annoyance. And it is constant, so, if you hate that then I’d avoid this game. Otherwise, the story as a whole is pretty decent, I think. You are on a quest to kill the “evil” [in your mind] emperor. You hire styx the goblin as a guide. Greenskins in general are persecuted, sometimes without reason.  But you still deal with humans plenty. Sometimes to do jobs, sometimes to get help, sometimes they are on your side from the start. You learn stories of other orcs and whatnot. I think styx is the only sentient goblin though. Voice acting is ok. Sometimes it’s pretty good, sometimes it can be bad. I think it kind of depends on the writing. Apparently this was made from a French studio, so some of it might be translation issues.The combat is where it really gets…iffy. Instead of, more or less, a hack and slash, you have a hack and slash via commands. When you enter combat, you hit space bar to go into super slow-mo, select a target and assign 4 actions to move through. The Orc is like a tank, kinda, except not a very good one. He can have an offensive stance or a defensive stance, though I haven’t really figured out if there is a difference. Then each stance has different things, like punch to stun, fast basic attack, powerful attack, round swinging attack that hits more than one enemy, etc. Enemies can parry and defend, but it just never seems to work all that well in general. Styx has melee attacks and ranged attacks. I usually stick to ranged if I can, but he usually gets surrounded anyway, and he’s pretty weak. With both guys I try go with a combo of stun and then smash, but it’s never totally clear what does what exactly. Combat is definitely the weakest part of this game. It’s interesting, it just doesn’t seem to be handled really well. Styx can also hide and do silent takedowns from behind, which is useful until you are spotted. So, TL:DR – decent game with some issues. Recommended in general, but it’s not for every one.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ber 11, 2016
												Of Orcs and Men is an interesting if rather flawed action RPG. The premise is certainly fairly unique, as instead of your usual heroes you control the berserker orc Arkail and the stealthy goblin Styx.The two protagonists are probably the best part of the game. Especially Styx is a great character with some great dialogue. The story itself is rather dark as befits such unusual "heroes".During combat you can slow time to issue commands which are then executed in real-time. The AI only uses the basic attacks so most of the time you have to control both characters manually. This works reasonably well on a gamepad, even if the controls can be little bit clunky at times. Unfortunately, the mouse and keyboard controls are pretty terrible and best avoided.Uninspired level design is another low point of the game. There are a few sidequests along the way, but the maps themselves are extremely linear and rather boring for the most part.Despite these flaws I'd recommend Of Orcs and Men to any action RPG fans looking for something little bit different. Just make sure you are playing with a gamepad.The good:- Great main characters, especially Styx- Interesting and fittingly dark story- Nice soundtrackThe bad:- Clunky controls, especially with mouse and keyboard- Extremely linear levels- Stealth mechanics are way too simple- Arkail's rage mechanic can be annoying at times- Item system is pretty boringThe ugly:- Some poor animations

That said I still liked the game, give it a whirl but stick with it at first - probably not got instant appeal.

content:
14, 2015
												I've had a blast playing through this game, and it's so extremely rare these days for any game to hold my attention for more than an hour. The story was pretty decent, dialogue was fantastic, and I was really attached to both of the main protagonists, since they were very likeable and relatable, despite being of otherworldly descent. Just be warned, there is quite a bit of swearing in the dialogue, but I thought the way it was done was creative. The whole narrative in this game is top notch.The combat system was fun and strategic, and the battles in general are quite challenging. Since this combat system is quite different to most RPGs, I'd personally suggest to play on Easy mode on the first playthrough, so to get acquainted with it.The game is quite linear. Most of its levels do tend to be a straight line, which will not appeal to players who like exploration, but I personally didn't mind the linear gameplay, because I enjoyed the story and the gameplay. In addition, you get a lot of sidequests in between. I was particularly impressed with a part of the game where you get to put together a squad and a plan of attack, and each little sidequest in that section actually counted towards it, which made them worth doing.Also worthy of note is the music. It was lovely to listen to and fit the scenes where it played perfectly.Overall I loved the game and I think it's very underappreciated. Would definitely recommend it and hope to see more games like this one from the devs behind it.

content:
9, 2015
												Of Orcs and Men is without a doubt the worst RPG game I ever played (and finished). It has serious issues. The pacing of the the storyline, the overall cut short game length, the corridor level design, the lack of enemy variety (there are only 5 types of character models in the whole game), shallow strategy, obstructive unadjustable camera, overly long cutscenes and the worst controlled in game target acquisition i have ever experienced. Sometimes my characters just deliberately ignored the appointed enemy and attacked what they felt like.I dont even know why i continued to play this game. The combat handling is unlike anything i have ever played before. This game does not know weather if it is a real time strategy game or a turn based RPG. The tutorial sequence is very short and taught me next to nothing at all. You get told pretty much nothing and have to inch yourself forward by trial and error. In fact the first 2 hours in this game were so bad i wanted to drop this game right on the floor.The character management is not very noteworthy. You have few items slots that can be filled with pretty much few identical items. If you ever go for a defensive stance you are pretty much ♥♥♥♥ed. You can never respecc your Status or Skill Tree Points. If you made a poor decision once, your are stuck with it until the end of the game. The fact that some of the enemy encounters are just outrageous and you need to kite them around obstacles just to not ♥♥♥♥ing die in the blink of an eye is just ridiculous. I'm looking at you, Dog Trainer. What the ♥♥♥♥ was Cyanide even thinking.I give this game credit. Cyanide made a bold move daring to create their own dark fantasy themed franchise in this overly bloated market. As i was able to experience in the later Installment of Styx: Master of Shadows the team has a vision. I would compare it the closest to Warhammer. Dont get me wrong, i am very glad they do something independent and different and as much as i wish i could like the game just for that, i can simply not.The graphic design of this game is acceptable to impressive. The main characters and the scenery stand out. They are nice examples of how to properly do greenskin characters. The sound design is acceptable. Fighting sounds and scenery music are good, though with 5 tracks a little short. Some of the characters have poor voice actors, while others have excellent ones. Styx ones is Excellent.This game back in the day when it was released was overhyped. I don't know where the problem was, that the team was too much occupied with the foundation build of a new engine and a new fantasy brand, but it really hurt the overall game. It did not age well. Its just too short and the levels string badly together. The first and second chapter are so long that you will spend approximately 75% of your playtime there. The 3 last sections are so short that i was confused to the point where I wondered if I have accidently skipped some missions. It doesnt help either that they cut out crucial parts of the story with drawn cut scenes where you could be there out in the field making the way with actual gameplay.It really is a regrettable waste of effort. If this game would have gotten a slightly bigger development team and about 6-12 months additional time, this may would have turned out to be an excellent game. Maybe even game of the year material 2013. But as it stands, Of Orcs and Goblins is a game only a RPG fan or a Ork enthusiast with a strong stomach can digest. I give it a 4 our of 10. Still , i hope Cyanide will just do the same as they Did with the stealth game in this series and deliver a new title that will surpass this one. The few times when the game was not teabagging me i was enjoying it. Remembered me of Metal Gear Rising a little. It has long elaborate cutscenes, which sadly can annoy or stress you at times. Some scenes were implemented poorly right in front of a difficult encounter and end up unskippable.The current asking price of 30 euros is a little high. I recommend you wait for a sale and get it when it is under 10. Playing warning is adviced. Play on own risk.

												I don't consider this videogame as RUBBISH. Many people think that but I disagree. Actually, I enjoyed the storyline. After all, you are an orc and not the usual human greenskins killer! The game has different defects. The animations are not really synchronized and the AI looks pretty stupid many times. Those must be improved in a sequel honestly. As I said before, the storyline is nice and I played it just for it. Actually, there are different side quests, but, actually, I don't know if they affect the story at all. Oh,yes, one more thing: In my opinion, the "missions" are too short. Most of the time you'll be watching videos. They are not that bad but I'd like to play something more too. The right balance should be found. I didn't pay for a movie, but a videogame ;). This may be exaggerated but, still,  the good balance must be found. I'd recommend this game if you wanna play a nice storyline and love orcs.

content:
, 2015
												Warning: There is not only no way to rebind controls ingame but it appears also not in the config files.Other than that it's an extremely linear game with highly repetitive combat. The story simply ticks all the boxes needed and nothing more though it does have two frankly unnecessary twists: one silly and one bloody obvious. The combat system is, as others have said, a little 'off' though still functional. It's a shame since the developers do seem to have really tried but the game just comes off as a bit boring.On the positive side the soundtrack was good, if a little repetitive, as were the graphics (both from a prettiness point of view and in terms of art style/matching the setting). The protagonists were also fun enough both individually and particularly when interacting with each other. The Stealth made for a nice change of pace and wasn't forced even in the specific stealth sections. I did enjoy picking off people slowly to make the inevitable fight easier on the big guy. The world could be interesting to revisit as it's just unique enough to interest me but it'd need a less repetitive game (preferably one with a working combat system).You'll probably get your money's worth if you pick it up on sale but there isn't much replayability unless you really enjoyed it.It might also have made for a good coop game.

content:
23, 2014
												Overall a great game. Probably one of the more enjoyable Action RPG with tactical pause in recent years for a number of reasons.Good visuals and 3rd persion with a great perspective and decent controls that works well with a keyboard and mouse. It just is very easy and clean once you understand it. Very well done story with decent voice acting.Itemization is a little simplistic yet effective. Inventory management and item upgrades are very streamlined for ease of use. Which struck me as a little odd given how challenging the game can be at times The end result is an interesting blend of streamlined yet difficult in that it requires planning and thought for how to approach fights. Stealth gameplay was very well done and incredibly effective at helping you to progress through the game.It is very linear however does not feel especially short or rushed. Limited character customizations outside of basic attributes and skill trees and there is no new game + so this not a game most will replay. I am the type of player who really likes exploring and finding all of the quests and yet doing that in this game I still could not break above 17.5 hours of gameplay. So while it is not too short it could have had a bit more content or at the very least new game+.Overall a solid 7 out of 10. Highly recommended at $15 or less.

content:
ber 29, 2016
												This might be my longest review yet so here's a TL;DR: Alright game that probably could've been amazing if it had more development.Of Orcs And Men is an Action-RPG type game where you get 3 sets of different moves you can use for 2 characters and you can input 4 at a time and they will initiate automatically when you choose who you want to attack. While the gameplay is somewhat unique I can't help but feel most of it is flawed in some way.Gameplay: One of the biggest problems I had with the game was that you get about 30 different skills that you can choose to unlock as you please, and also assign skill points when you level up, but a good portion of the skills seem to be near useless or have barely noticable results. Throughout most of the game you rely on the goblin, Styx, for the majority of the fights whether you're using the extremely OP stealth mode to take out as many enemies before you have to initiate a fight or having to almost ALWAYS use the "Armor-piercing" skill since a majority of the enemies get tons of armor that you need to break down. Area of Effect skills also seem to have a bigger priority over every other type of skill. Arkail, the orc, compared to Styx is almost completely useless in most cases if not only to be a hit-sponge distraction to ensure Styx never gets attacked. He can also build up enough rage to go into Berserker mode yet that is entirely useless and often does more harm than good. You also can't see the amount of Dodge/Deflection an enemy has until you're attacking them and you notice they constantly Dodge/Deflect your attacks. In the end the gameplay wasn't horrible but it definitely left a bit of a sour aftertaste with me.Story(probably spoilers): The story was honestly pretty good. You play from the perspective of an exiled orc who's people are being hunted down and enslaved for the glory of the human empire and you are tasked with killing the Emperor. You're accompanied by the only intelligent Goblin in the world, Styx, who helps you get over the Wall and decides to stay with you for the entire journey. Arkhail has a strong racial bias against Styx in the beginning and Styx is just looking to get paid, but eventually they become good pals after they witness the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ conditions that orc slaves must endure and even witness each other's troubling pasts. They even gain some human allies along the way showing that not everyone supports the orc's enslavement and befriend some mages too. In the end you kill the Emperor, but it was just a trap to turn the elves and dwarves against the orcs as well as make some ♥♥♥♥♥♥ the new Emperor. Then you kill the Emperor again and you kill the super evil, super strong wizard leader of the Inquisition. The last boss was pretty disappointing since it was very easy compared to a lot of other tough fights and the game ends with Arkhail and Styx being happy but now everyone, except the few mages left, is waging war on the dwindling orc race. The voice acting wasn't terrible but it has some very amateur moments and could've used some work. One thing that really surprised me as well was that nearly all the orcs and goblin talked exactly like a human compared to having an odd accent or speaking in strange tones.Everything else: For a 2012 game the graphics are slightly underwhelming, but it wasn't a big enough problem to make me stop playing. Some areas randomly drop frames quite a bit but the majority of the game was stable. The AI was a bit shoddy at times as well ranging from enemies or even my partner getting stuck on other people or objects in the environment. The music was quite good at some parts, but it wasn't anything special. Why did I make such a long review for this game? It's not everyday you get a fantasy game where you play as orcs who are on the morally good side and the world is quite different from the typical Tolkien/Warhammer fantasy. Like I said in the beginning, the game had a very promising start but it seems as though there was a major lack of development that set it to be just "alright" even though the game was published by Focus Home Interactive who has supported a large amount of other games(some being Warhammer based). Of Orcs And Men is definitely worth at least one playthrough and at most ~$10 on sale, but don't go into it expecting anything amazing.

r 18, 2015
												This is a really nice looking game, with an interesting story, and a unique angle. I like the characters, and the voice acting is pretty good. The concept is excellent. What a shame, then, that the mechanics are complete crapola.Did you play KOTOR and think, "Wow, this combat is too much fun. I don't think I can handle having this much fun. If only someone could do something similar, but make it boring and terrible."? If you did, then congrats, I've found the perfect game for you. Everyone else should stay away. This game would be better served by simple hack and slash combat, or Final Fantasy style turn based combat, or even a freaking DDR pad for me to stomp on to complete combat. Hell, it would have been better with no actual combat and just cutscenes showing combat. That's how bad the combat is - it would have been better if they had done nothing at all, because this combat is less than nothing.The other mechanics aren't exactly brilliantly done either. The camera zooms in on an orc's massive back, and you can't zoom it out, so his shoulders take up about half of your screen width. The parts of the scenery I could see past his massive back looked nice, though.This was a major disappointment. So much potential thrown directly into the trash.

er 26, 2015
												FIRST IMPRESSIONSPROS:GRAPHICS: Gorgeous. It is the right balance, everything goes together and nothing really "sticks out." It's dark and secretive befitting the setting.STORY: Interestingly attractive. At first, because we are all human, we think we get to play the anti-hero; but then, we realize we are actually playing the role of legitamate heroes, attempting to kill the man enslaving your people (though killing inocents still make you evil lol).CONS:LANGUAGE: Quite honestly the languae is immediatly offputting and breaks immersion. Having served in the military I am mainly desensitized to foul language and I understand and agree in some games colorful dialouge can inhance the tension or emotion of the scene. But this is basically a twelve year old trying to sound edgy by dropping the F-bomb every other sentence. It doesn't even flow with the characters themselves. It even happens in casual conversations between characters who seem to be friends. It's as if the voice actors who were hire are so stuck on their automatic swearing they couldn't turn it off just to make a game. Where are the antequated euphamisms, or the fantasy twinge on standard words (Frak anyone?), or even just making it more appropriate to the story? When he refered to Styx as vermin in the Orcish tounge that was great, but this school yard "look at me I give the game a mature rating" edgespeak is just a joke. It isn't offensive, it is annoying.MECHANICS: As mentioned in several reviews the mechanics are a bit "meh." The near time-stop action que is a great idea, but you feel like your character is always 3 actions behind everyone else. Not to mention there is no command for movement when in this menu.6/10 Get it on sale.

content:
r 13, 2014
												You tell your characters who to target, and 4 attacks to do, then watch them go. If you interupt them, you lose that attack and can actually fight with the character to try to make them run out of combat, cause the character wants to stay in combat.It seems fun. But as the butcher I want to pound everything, and as the goblin I want to sneak and do stealth kills. But mixing them both together is too weird for me. Once in the fight, the goblin seems useless, compared to the strength of the orc. Before the fight, sneaking for that one hit kill seems enjoyable.Actually there were only two things wrong with this game. The swearing is out of place. Its like the characters didnt really want to swear, but the script said they had to. Which comes off really aweful. In real life when someone is gonna drop the f bomb, they are either mad or frustrated. In this game, its like they are trying to describe the color blue. It just doesnt fit. "That battle is blue!" hm... "That battle is blue man!" naw... "That blue battle is blue man..." ok... I'll just have to play again and get the exact phrases, so I can make fun of them properly.Gaining xp through fights is what it seemed I wanted, which brings me to...The second thing wrong was that I chose to take "the hard way", and started a fight with an orc traitor, which started a war that I couldn't handle. I was fine having the orc fight a 4 human team, but when I tried to involve the goblin... he took off running past the soldiers I was fighting, down an alley, and into a whole nother area, where he attacked a whole new squad of soldiers. This agroed too many soldiers on my team, which killed them both fast. You can't get away.On reload I noticed I could not start previous to where I chose the hard way... in fact, it auto-saved right after I made that poor choice. So I tried again, and the misfit team just cant handle a single squad of soldiers for some reason. So I have to start completely over... next time I will save more often.In retrospect, maybe this game would be better if thought of as an incredibly interactive movie. Next time I play, I will keep that in mind.

												Only just gets the thumbs up.  Looks like yet another action-RPG mass-produced from a basic stencil, just with the graphic set adjusted and a few changes made to menus and such like (here the production company uses the in-house Silk engine instead of UnrealEngine3, but from appearances both are very similar).  There are a lot of them about and almost none has anything to lift it above the others.  This one just pips the entry-level competition to the post by virtue of the character Styx, a slightly cynical wise guy who has seen it all.  He has his own game, Styx Master of Shadows, which is really quite good, possibly better than this one because it draws you in, and this one doesn't have a lot going for it in that department.  The storyline appears to be pretty basic.  It relies a lot on keeping you wondering if it's going to get any better.  I'll add another comment if that does in fact prove to be the case.  But don't wait up, so far it's been a dreary string of learning-curve chores and irrelevent mini-tasks instead of a Hero's Quest.

content:
29, 2016
												Rating 7/10Overview: Third Person Tactical RPGThe Good:+ Artistically and technically I thought the graphics were good. Every chapter has a unique atmosphere so the setting never gets repetitive. + I like playing as an orc and a goblin, it provides a unique twist to an otherwise standard formula seen in so many other fantasy RPGs. Both characters are well written and excellently voice. The relationship between the two is what holds the entire game together. + Each character has two main skill trees to choose from to fit your play style. Although it becomes pretty apparent that certain skill trees/skills are more powerful and practical than others. The Average:The story is decent but never really evolves into anything. The entire premise is explained in the first hour of the game and never deviates. Other than the main characters, no other character is given a lot of dialogue so it becomes hard to care about the villains or side characters.  The first two chapters take a while to complete, both of these chapters have side quests. The other remaining chapters are much shorter making the game have a very uneven pace. Un-skippable cut scenes. Normally I would consider this very bad, however this game has very little cut scenes and are not very long. The Bad:The levels are REALLY linear with the occasional off beaten path that usually leads to a chest. Thus, every level plays out almost exactly the same. Run through a corridor beat down some enemies, rinse and repeat until the end. The combat is identical to that of Knights of the Old Republic. I hated it back then and I hate it now. You give a series of commands and sit back and watch as the character executes them, keep doing this until all the enemies are dead. The combat is not engaging, gets very repetitive and once you have your favorite skills unlocked gets even more boring.  Conclusion:Your enjoyment of the game will be largely dependent on how much you enjoy the main characters. It's a decent game given the budget the developers had to work with.

content:
r 20, 2015
												Let me start by saying this game is awful. Please, save your money and don't buy it.●▬▬▬▬ஜ۩۞۩ஜ▬▬▬▬● ×°×★Summary Review★×°×Overall Rating: ★☆☆☆☆ [1/5]Story: ★☆☆☆☆Gameplay: ★☆☆☆☆Sound: ★☆☆☆☆●▬▬▬▬ஜ۩۞۩ஜ▬▬▬▬●I've tried and tried to give this game a chance, but after 3 hours all I can conclude is that this is a prime example of a great idea gone wrong. Thanks to misguided game-tags this is being sold to players as an "Action, RPG, Story Rich" title. I'll tell you right now it is none of these things.First of all, the combat is clunky, even fans of this terrible game will tell you that's true. The combat is slow and strategy based, NOT an action game. Action games are free-flowing with non-stop "action" like Space Marine, Tomb Raider 2013, and Dragonball Xenoverse. Those are action games, this is not.And regarding the RPG elements, it's very easy to completely screw yourself if you don't spend your skill points in the right way. If that happens, you'll find yourself at the end of the game unable to finish, forcing you to start all over again, because there's no way to undo your skill points. This completely defeats the purpose of customization, which is the core element of an RPG.Secondly, the dialog feels like it was writen by a 13 year old trying to sound cool by swearing all the time. Honestly, there's no need for that much cursing. I'm by no means offended by it, it just doesn't feel appropriate to what's going on in the story. And the rest of the dialog is just, well, awful. Nothing about it is immersive.Story Rich? Really? Who tagged this game with that? Because it's not. The story is nothing more than your basic "Orcs VS Humans" genre. The original Warcraft had a better story to it than this. Either the developers didn't have a big enough budget to afford decent writers or they just didn't care. However, the end result is the same. A lack-luster experience that left me feeling cheated out of my money. There's no way in hell this game is worth $30. Maybe $9. Maybe. But it would still be awful.

												Sad to say but I have to put a negative review on this game which is a shame really because the story is VERY very good. The issue is however that the game doesn't scale very well in difficulty. It scales about as well as if you were playing a JRPG and didn't grind nor buy any new equipment, despite me doing that in this game. I scowered for secrets and instead of making it seems like "You found a really awesome peice of a equipment, enemies can't touch you" or "You found a awesome sword that has the ability to stun" all it is, is a increase in damage which sounds nice and the upgrades you can get make some items 10x more effective, but the game seems to scale up to match this.So much so that the part I was stuck on, the Orc had no armour or weapons (besides a giant stick)  but the goblin had the equipment, so I end up dying as the enemies are fighting me in the same quality as if I was fully decked out in all the best gear I worked hard with side missions to get and even then it only made battle difficulty scaled down to just above average.Most of these issues come down to the combat system. Fact is, you don't pause in combat but merely slow it down and as both your characters are mellee types (if we were to lable them classes, the Orc is a Barbarian and the Goblin is a Rogue) you have no ability to heal yourself. There is a potion ability the barbarian gets, but all that does is increase health regeneration which isn't the same thing.Steal elements are a joke at times. Sometimes I'm able to kill one guard next to another one and other times not. When dogs get introduced one of the tips is (don't try to assassinate the dogs. They can also smell you from a mile away so be careful) yet I've killed guards that were standing right behind the dogs and they didn't notice. Even though you turn transparaent when in stealth mode, moving in front of someone's vision will get you spotted.It seems like there are many abilities and choices for an ability, which is locked in, unfortunatly it seems the game is designed for a very specific ability choices and bonuses and to level your characters up in such a specific way that one mis-placed point and you will mess up your character. the creators were also responsible for that terrible Game of Thrones RPG which had an even worse combat system to it.That only good thing about it is the story and the twist on it being your heroes are the creatures usually considered monsters and evil, but here they are being invaded and enslaved by the human Empire and their plan is to kill the Emporor in hopes of destroying or atleast destabalising the empire and there is a religous side to it involving religious fanatics that have powers and spells.I'd recommend you just watch the cut-scenes online or someone's let's play because the game itself is generally not very user-friendly and very unfriendly to first-timers on the game too.

content:
er 15, 2014
An astounding soundtrack and two well crafted main characters aren't enough to make Of Orcs and Men worth recommending.For a game released in Oct. 2012 this game feels like it could have come out nearly a decade earlier (aside from its graphics). This is a painfully linear game. The vast majority of it is spent running through brown and gray winding corridors with evenly spaced groups of enemies to encounter. What choices you are able to make, both in moving about the world and within the story, ultimately don't have much real impact. The voice acting for the two main characters, Arkail and Styx, is high quality but the remaining cast ranges from bad to atrocious.The major selling point for this game, playing from the greenskins' perspective, is implemented with mixed success. The character arcs of Arkail and Styx are both enjoyable. Their personality's balance each other out with Arkail being the brawn and honor type and Styx being the brainy and cautious one. Unfortunately the game follows a lot of stereotypes in terms of orc behavior and in a storyline centering around slaves revolting against power hungry evil rulers. Change the orcs into humans from a warrior tribe led by shamans and very little would change. That makes the story feel more human relatable but also cheapens the greenskins' perspective feature, making it seem like more of a surface change or gimmick.A lot of reviewers have commented negatively on the excessive use of foul language and I'm inclined to agree. It's not that I am offended by the words but that it feels forced, like a misguided attempt to make the game more dark and gritty. The script is otherwise decent with Styx's dialogue being the best it has to offer ranging down to some of its one dimensional villains being its worst.I enjoyed the combat during the middle hours of the game but not in the remaining hours. At the start your options are limited before you unlock more attacks and there is a bit of an awkward learning curve. Later on, the repetition got to me as the same strategy that worked early in the game worked all the way through, making most fights feel the same. Styx's ability to stealth assassinate enemies before you are spotted was a feature that I eventually stopped bothering with. I found it wasn't necessary to win most fights, slowed things down and wasn't particularly fun.Of Orcs and Men's biggest success in my opinion is its soundtrack. It stands out with a unique style that features a lot of cello and drums. As soundtracks often go, not every track is interesting but on the whole I found it catching my ear numerous times throughout the game.There are situations where I would recommend Of Orcs And Men but overall I didn't find this game to be good enough to recommend to most people. For example, diehard action RPG fans who have already exhausted the higher rated games in the genre might find something worth playing here.

content:
29, 2016
												Disappointing.  Let me start by staying, I love the concept, to play as  an orc fighting humans for once, and the developers have created a rich & detailed world with interesting lore, as well as two well-written & interesting main characters. I'll happily read novels set in this world.  And the graphics are pretty good.But everything else about this game is painfully uninspired.  Every level is a corridor, and some have long stretches with neither enemies nor points of interest.  Loot is rare and frequently boring, the skill-trees are uninteresting, and while combat has a novel design allowing you to switch between the characters & queue up actions, the result delivers neither interesting tactical challenges, or good action sequences.  Hard fights often find you leading your enemies in circles while trying to revive your other character - and this is not helped by comically bad hit detection that can see you killed by a swordstrike from 20 feet away.

												So, for what it is I absolutely loved Of Orcs And Men. It's a pretty bare-boned RPG to be sure, with only a handful of locations and only two playable characters, but what was awesome about it, to me, was the story, and how it was presented. I loved the portrayal of orcs as a subjugated race trying to cling to their old ways of honor and dealing with the corruption of man. I loved the back and forth relationship between Arkail and Styx as they adventure together.The combat system is pretty cool, too. It goes into slow-mo while you Queue up actions, and you can scout ahead and stealth kill dudes with the goblin before charging in to mop up with the orc, letting you approach encounters how you want for the most part.Definitely worth a play through if you like story and orcs.

content:
ber 11, 2014
												Of Orcs and Men may not be a perfect game but it is a great game that tells an amazing story. I loved the characters and the quest they where on. It really was a wonderful change of pace. The RPG elements of the game where not the greatest and combat was normally a little repetative but both where still very enjoyable and reminded me of a more basic version of Dragon Age.During my first play through I felt that the developers idea of making a challenging fight was to simply "crank it up to 11" but after playing it once though I was able to get a better idea for what worked well and rarely ran into anything "unfair" during the game.The only thing that really dragged the game down was the lackluster level design. Most levels are very linear and basic. There was mention of how the goblin Styx could go places Arkail the orc could not at the start of the game but I think this was only implemented two or three times in the game and the few times I could do it I felt like it didn't make a difference. On top of that some of the character design for the supporting characters was, well, total crap. Although the main characters where very well done for the most part, the majority of the enemies where extremely generic and skins where recycled generously. These are small complaints though as the focus of this game is on Arkail and Styx and the wonky NPC's don't detract fromt he experience too much.Over all though I still highly recomend this game. I loved it. The stories of Arkail and Styx are inspiring and by themselves make the game worth every penny. I have shamelessly stolen a lot of the ideas behind the plot of this game for a Dungeons and Dragons campaing I have been running for three years now and the players love it. Now that I have beat the game twice I can't wait to give the prequal, Styx: Master of Shadows, a try.

content:
er 25, 2015
												(I did not complete the game!) Honestly I have tried to like and complete  this game.  I have tried to play this game many times, but here are some positives about the game Of Orcs and Men.  The story for this game is different in a way that make you appreciate the bruiting orc or the snarky goblin you play as.  Instead of a regular redemption story this felt like more along the line of revenge with somewhat of a redemption story which is great twist that you sometime don't see in some big AAA games. Here is somethings that I did not like about the game that is keeping me from completion.I did not like the battle system for this game.  It seemed like it was based from Knights of the Old Republic but instead of having a party of 3 or even 4 you only have 2.  You are given a warrior and a rogue in your party which for me caused a lot of issues for the many plain and difficult battles. The battles did not seem to be designed well and I felt like I was over powered most of the time.  Boss battles are not well designed and are not memorable by any means. The one good thing you could do to make a battle easier was to get stealth kills, but you had to balance not being seen while having your other companion who could not use stealth be somewhat close before engaging in another battle.  This would allow you to get some stealth kills in but it wouldn't take long before someone seen your other companion and engaged battle.  When I normally play games I try to play on the default setting which would normally be on normal but this is the first game where I felt so overpowered on normal I had to switched it to easy and I still feel like I am overpowered.  To me the loot system they had in this game was not needed and felt very shallow.I am not going to talk about the art in this game because I may not like it but others might. This is my review on the game, so I hope that this is useful.

content:
y 24, 2016
												Let me start with the cons:- The game has just rudimentary systems and gameplay. The stats don't matter for the most part and only few skills open up new combat strategies. Most numbers and stats are not important (+5% dodge or +10% dodge? +2 Mind or +2 Stamina? Doesn't really matter).- The level design is very linear, there is nothing to explore. Regardless of whether you are in the catacombs, the forest or the monastery, all levels are just corridors.- The quest design is similarly simplistic. There are only a few sidequests and they don't really matter. There are almost no choices and consequences. In the middle of the game there is one interesting series of choices but there is no sign later whether it changes anything. The game plays more like a linear adventure with stat-based combat than an RPG.Despite that I recommend the game. Why?- The main characters are what drew me forward. Arkail and Styx are superbly written and voiced. As you play on, their relationship develops and they both confront their past. Styx especially is wonderfully sarcastic and misanthropic and it never grows stale, even until the final cutscene.- The music is wonderful.- The environment styles are also nice (apart from the catacombs, those were boring). Especially in the later parts of the game.I found the gameplay in Bound By Flame, Mars: War Logs and Of Orcs And Men similarly repetitive. But this was the most compelling game of the three for me, mostly because of the two protagonists, whose story I wanted to see till the end.

content:
ry 10, 2016
												in the end it was a coin toss, literally, head said 'not recommended'. shame steam doesnt have a neutral recommendation.for me, it was a slightly enjoyable experience with a lot of frustration. mind you, not exactly my genre - i like rpgs and can enjoy action titles with some kind of character development but i was on the edge with this one the whole time.so i will enumerate my laments (he-he) but keep in mind that the game has some nice features too, but you should read about them in the 'recommended' reviews. i will not even try to seem objective, not my, heh, objective (i know, goal, aim etc).-well its more or less hack 'n slash, im not much for it, but it cant be helped, i wasnt the target audience. but for me it seemed that at least the half of the many attacks/abilities were only to fill the place. in a good game there should be purpose or at least a niche for every one. balance?-the maps were very linear, also a bane of the genre so i shouldnt criticize the game for it but i do, and even more so when i just run through half of the map for nothing, no loot, no enemies.-maybe the creators were so proud of their product that they wanted to show off the scenery but although there were some eye catching design elements the graphics were not very convincing for a 2012 game.-the voice acting was superb most of the time but there were a few clear miscasts eg raven. also if you have to wait for your mate every 2 minutes, there should have been a greater variety of clips reminding you, i was both annoyed by the fact that my buddy was too back for the games taste and also by the message telling me so.-btw, if i want to explore the (not too big) map with styx slahing throats here and there maybe i shouldnt have have to wait for ark at the door of every second room. hey, some freedom? some immersion or something?-music was nice, atmospheric but forgettable. nothing to criticize here and nothing to remember, did its job.-i dont see why almost all good items were placed in the first act. after that i picked up a few here and there but very few really more useful, i mostly did it for variety. balance?-i still cant understand why developers think that its a good idea to make those who ultimately pay their salaries watch their logos every time the game is started. its an old grievance of mine and im certain im not alone with this. remember dawn of war (the first one)? you had to watch the intros for the first time (and it was sooo cool), after that, you could skip it. if you cant achieve that, let me skip it the first time. i didnt pay to suffer, thanks.-ah, you say, why dont you just alttab from the game instead of quitting? that way you can minimize your watching them again. and again. and again. 1. sometimes after alttabbing the music stays on, so you have to mute it and then unmute it, doable of course but inconvinient; 2. once i couldnt manually save after coming back from desktop. but of course i didnt know that was the reason, i thought the game is screwing with me not letting me save (in a way it did), and that was the first time i almost uninstalled it as i had to fight through some hard battles and when i died i had to start anew from much further. alttabbing btw: they still did much better job than bethesda - they cant solve this conundrum (among others) since morrowind (2002!)...-ah, battles? you have a map where you p1ss blood to survive (and i dont mean bosses) and the next five is cakewalk. again, balance?-i felt i spent too much time watching cutscenes. dont misunderstand me, i like meself a good story but it seemed to me sometimes that i have to watch 5 minutes of cutscenes to play the same amout of time. maybe i just wanted to get over with this game to start another with better entertainment/frustration ratio, i dont know, i generally like these story elements.-you cannot skip all cutscenes. im at the endgame where i failed twice miserably and i have to watch half of the damned talking to try again, and of course no saves between battles. thanks, devs. im not sure im willing to do it more than 1 or 2 times more and however i hate to leave a game unfinished, especially so close to its ending theres a good chance that i will in this case.all in all with some polishing and playtesting, balancing the powers/items/battles this could have been a much better title.my story with of orcs and men: i followed news about it. it was released, i waited for sale, bought it on sale. waited to have some time to play it. quite liked it but was somewhat annoyed. run into the alttab-nosave problem, almost deleted it. i enjoyed somewhat more after that. searched for the styx game, addet to wishlist. got to the end, got frustrated, removed styx from my wishlist and i will try again the endgame for a few times.now, despite all the criticism above, dont be (completely) disheartened: this game have some nice features and might be much more entertaining for you than it was for me. if you love the genre and you feel you can forgive the problems above, go give it a try. i almost gave it a 'slightly recommended' but the coin thought otherwise.EDIT: i could beat zealot for the 3rd try somehow, so i have finished the game. still, this fact does not much to redeem the game as a whole, so the 'not recommended' flag stays. this means i also got to the end credits, where the playtesters were listed: all 6 of them. that is not too many and i am sorry but it showed.

												I found this to be a surprisingly good game once you get past the first couple of hours.  It put me off right at the start - The poor/average voice acting, the need to swear every other word and the combat as well (It's more or less like Knights of the Old Republic, but less fun), but once I'd levelled up a bit and got the story rolling it was surprisingly engrossing.  By using hotkeys for skills, as the game suggests (and you even get an achievement for it), combat felt much, much smoother.On the downside, the final act of the game felt rushed and the ending isn't subtle about setting up a sequel that hasn't happened yet.

content:
2, 2013
												It feels like the storywriters had a really solid idea, but didn't have the budget to pull it off. There's the feel of a setting that's interesting, even if no one single element is original, the combination is. You play the last great hero of the orcs, sent on a one-way mission to avoid the final genocide of your race by assassinating the human emperor. But while you move through a non-standard fantasy story, the gameplay is the most railroaded since Railroad Tychoon 2: the Railroading. There's ONE way through each map, and usually only one valid tactic in each fight. Your sole impact on the game is the choice of skills, which don't actually change what the characters can do, just how well they do it. And by the endgame, it seems clear that most people will have identical skill trees anyway.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
er 21, 2013
												Of Orcs And Men has all the qualities of a great book: it lures you into its story and you are constantly interested in what will happen next. Character interaction isn't forced by putting them around a campfire at night and boasting stories over roast pig. We hear little of their stories, and we learn of the main characters by how they talk to eachother and to others, and you learn more about them in a good pace across the game.Sadly, it also has flaws that comes with trying to simulate a good book in a videogame: the level designs and progress through the game are very linear, where the few stray paths are there to provide a little more gear, experience and sometimes a bit of story. The combat itself reminds me of Dragon Age 2, where you can queue up abilities in a slow-motion menu, where it is then executed in real-time. There's no shortage of abilities, but beyond the Rage and Concentration system, there isn't a very unique combat style. (In fact, on harder difficulties, certain abilities and builds are so much more effective than others, that combat itself can become repetitive).The blend of shallow RPG-elements but great story elements does make it fun to play however. If you take all the optional sidequests, routes and talk with every NPC, the game has a surprisingly large amount of content. With only three achievements dependant on multiple choice, it's possible to get every achievement in the game with two instances of reloading to a previous save.A few last special notions to some of the more memorable notions of the game: it's graphics, it's world and it's soundtrack.The graphics aren't very high-end, and with some ofthe more advanced games around, you won't be impressed. But it does a good job at imitating them, without being very demanding on your hardware.The world it plays in is different from other fantasy RPGs - that much should be clear by the title alone! It's one of the few recent RPG-releases that's more interested in painting morals gray than black-and-white.The soundtrack is from the Boston Cello Quartet, and is an absolute gem. It's also implemented into the game to play/loop certain parts of a soundtrack at certain points of combat/cutscenes; the soundtrack itself syncs with your level progression.Of Orcs And Men is a good recommendation, and it's a shame that Spiders Studio confirmed there are currently no plans for a much desired sequal. I personally found the price a bit too steep, but thankfully, Steam regulary allows sales and I managed to get Of Orcs And Men for a considerable discount.

content:
er 29, 2012
												This game is very well made.  Its primary method of play is strategy of combat.  You are provided with two protagonists, an Orc and a Goblin.  Most obviously, one is a brutish tank capable of dealing extreme damage and taking punishment, and the other is stealthy assassin capable of fighting both in melee and range, and is better suited to the delicate tasks.  That said, the impressive thing is how well the two characters pair in order to provide an excellent play experience.The story behind the game is well written, and the voice acting for the characters is rather excellent.  The protagonists being an orc and a goblin is exciting, even if some of the storyline elements can be viewed as cliche.  In fact, the voice acting and writing is so well done it makes it obvious that the 'conversation' animations are limited.  That said, the limited animations feel 'right' to both the dialog and the gameplay.  Of Orcs and Men is a game that focuses on the well defined and executed gameplay, rather than the shiny baubles most companies seem to focus their efforts on in order to distract the player from poor gameplay.  The pairing of the characters, and the inner dichotomies of their skill wheels provides rich gameplay for the mostly well designed battles and encounters.  Perhaps the most frustrating of encounters are the boss battles, because your have less time and space to plan and execute battle strategy, but it's just one more layer to an interesting game and story.

content:
er 6, 2013
												A diamond on the rough! Of Orcs and Men is nothing short of a compelling tale of a reverse good-vs-evil plot. Although not necessarily a style only seen under fantasy, high or low, storylines, OO&M tackles those elements and tackles them HARD. Be ready to have some of your pre-conceived notions of fantasy twisted in a way that not even Shrek could come up with - and with a much more serious tone. Watch out for foul language (there is a LOT) if you'd like to avoid it. If you don't mind it like me, this will just bring much more life to this already vibrant world (after all, a rough orc and a shifty goblin aren't old ladies nor are their usual repertoire). Nevertheless, there are some flaws: animation is pretty damn bad (the persistent use of the blatant same animations reminds me of KotOR of all things, in a sense that you can tell which animation is being used - for the 100th time), so is voice acting for anyone outside the main cast (although Arkail and Styx, the protagonists, sound perfectly as they should) and graphics are okay, at best - a medium-end machine or lower can play it maxed and indeed enjoy some good visuals. I also dislike how pretty much every section of the game is structured as a "corridor": you have optional pathways, but it really works as a road with just one blatant way to go - instead of a dungeon-crawler, this is a corridor-crawler.The fascinating story, the likeable characters (despite sometimes feeling too one-dimensional, until late chapter 2, when things begin heating up) and the intriguing, almost turn-based, and simple (if played on easy) yet complex (on hard and *gasp* the frustratingly challenging Extreme difficulties) combat kept me going despite the flaws.Really enjoyed playing the game and I'm definetly playing it again sometime in the future. As well as keeping an eye out for future games from these devs.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2015
												The short version: This game, overall better than mediocre. The story was interesting; the graphics were fair; the controls were good. 'Of Orcs And Men' had a lot of potential to be a GREAT game, but some of it's bugs and shortcomings bring it down. Nevertheless, I recommend giving it a play-through.--- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- ---I will not rehash the concept behind 'Of Orcs And Men'; there are plenty of reviews which lay out the concepts of this title. What will follow is a collection of problems I had with 'Of Orcs And Men'.Graphics: Character designs for anything that's not a goblin or orc are painfully mediocre. Humans and dogs are bland at best, and many of their animations are very stiff. Shadow quality is poor. Many of the animations, particularly in cut-scenes, can be a bit jittery.Dialogue: The early game is pretty good. Arkail and Styx were done mostly well throughout the game. Other voice actors are often bland, wooden, or outright BAD. The voice work for the one dwarf in the game is HORRIBLE, sounding as though it may have been "read" by a computer generated voice... it was THAT BAD!General Combat: Throughout 'OOAM' you will very often find yourself swarmed by small hordes of enemies. This is great, as it lends to the sense of awesomeness of the protagonists. Many of your combat abilities cause crowd control effects, such as stun, which are often necessary to survive some encounters. While it's understandable for some enemies to be more resistant to these effects than others, there seems to be an anti-CC-lock mechanic in place, which seems to prevent MOST enemies from being stunned more that once or twice. This would be great if it worked both ways! I found in some combats, particularly those with magic-wielding Inquisitors, that the enemy's ability to unerringly CC you can easily lead to your death if one of your characters falls, making it impossible for the conscious character to rouse the unconscious one.A.I. Combat: Arkail and Styx are a team. You can control either character, and whichever you are not controlling is directed by the A.I. when not given a list of specific commands, or when that list runs out. Additionally, if you are scouting ahead with Styx, and get detected, Arkail will not automatically run to his side to fight with him! This can be particularly tricky if there is a bit of distance between the characters. Opening up the command menu will slow time to a crawl, allowing you to issue commands, but you can only move the characters in real time, and you can't control them both at the same time. This often leads to having to run Styx back to wherever you left Arkail, who will be waiting there with a thumb up his .... Adding to the A.I. combat frustration, stuns and other such crowd control effects used against you will not only interrupt the character while trying to execute a command, it will often clear their command queue, meaning they will not resume the queue once the effect has passed. This can often be detrimental, particularly in cases where you've queued a character to perform a vital self-heal.A.I. Pathing: There are many points where one character will get stuck and not follow the lead character (especially if you're scouting with Styx.) Additionally, there are a few locations where even the character you're controlling won't respond to a given command due to a pathing problem. What's worse, this often leads to enemies (at least the melee variety) completely ignoring that character and ganging up on the other one. If the "invisible" character is Arkail, be prepared to watch Styx meet his doom VERY QUICKLY!Miscellaneous Issues: 1. While the story for 'Of Orcs And Men' is fairly interesting, some of the conversations can be painfully length, especially in a few of the scenarios where you have died (sometimes multiple times) and are forced to repeat a lengthy bit of dialogue. This can be even more obnoxious if the game won't allow you to skip the dialogue. 2. The armor upgrade system is extremely simple, giving every item in the game a single upgrade. What's more, the game does not give you any sort of preview as to how much this will improve an item. At early stages, when trade points are sparse, it can be quite irritating to upgrade an item only to find your currently equipped gear is still better. At later stages, when you have mages who can supposedly "enhance" your equipment, this could have been made significantly more interesting by adding effects to gear rather than the same enhancements you would get from any other merchant you had dealt with at earlier points. Equipment upgrading was very lackluster. 3. Saving, at later stages in the game, is virtually pointless OR inaccessible, forcing you to rely on autosaves, as you may be forced to soldier on through a series of several combats before the next save. This was particularly obnoxious at the end of the game, as a death with the boss fight would force replaying three or four consecutive combats AND a lengthy, unskippable dialogue scene. 4. Arkail's weapon after loading. It seemed that after every break (quitting the game, and loading it back up at a later time), Arkail's weapon would no longer look like what he had equipped, and would instead look like a simple stick/club. It wasn't until near the end of the game I realized this was because Arkail would somehow unequip his weapon upon reloading the game! This is a minor issue, as you simply have to re-equip his weapon, but this shouldn't even happen in the first place. I also had this happen randomly during play, usually after the occasional cut-scene. 5. At a late point in the game, both Arkail and Styx are each given the choice between two advancement paths which grant access to additional abilities. The game does not give any indication as to what the different advancement paths with grant, so players who are more interested in the abilities they will gain rather than the story reason for selecting a given path will find this lack of insight a bit irritating. 6. Styx is all about stealth, but this option becomes an increasingly less viable option the more the story advances. I found there was almost no point to stealth at the end game. Dogs cannot be assassinated, very few enemies are positioned in ways which allow for stealth kills, and those who are are often extremely weak anyway, so there is not much point to wasting time with sneaking. As a proponent of stealth-based games, I found this highly disappointing. Additionally, the few times where you are forced to play solo as Styx, you are thrust into the combat with no option for approaching with stealth. If you don't build Styx to be tough (focusing on Stamina), this can make for a ludicrously difficult combat.General Gameplay Weakness: While there are many options available to the player as they advance Styx and Arkail, the best option is to focus on Arkail's defensive abilities and Styx's ranged abilities. Optimally, focusing on Stamina for both these characters will make them extremely tough, and make the game far easier to beat. Essentially, this is the only "right" way to play, particularly at the higher difficulty settings.--- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- ---All that said, the game was very engrossing. When I would play, several hours would easily pass, and I didn't want to stop until I had finished.

I mean you are surrounded by enemy's and you can not activate one skill or run away. You tell your character which enemy to attack but your character do nothing or attack the wrong guy. The moment you accepted a request you wont be able to cancel it later in-game. er 23, 2013
												TL;DR, Orcs swear so much, a sailor would be offended. Speaking as not a sailor, I still don't like it.It may be a good looking RPG but the dialogue is pretty bad. The only way that the writers thought to convey that the orcs were angry was to add common swears such as "F*ck" and "s*it" into the dialogue. And for me, that really puts me off. I mean moderate curses throughtout the dialogue would have been better to deal with but in nearly every dialogue it's just said almost nonchalantly. It's not a make or break deal for the game but it does make me lose interest and any sense of immersion pretty fast.Maybe the game gets better after you stomach through the bad dialogue choice. I wouldn't know. I was captivated by the thought of the story and how it seemed like it was a different RPG -styled game. I was deterred after the dialogue made every bit of my immersion shatter like a windscreen underneath a 100 foot towering tree. But hey. If you don't mind the constant "f*ck this" or whatever, then by all means. It's got pretty grpahics and all that and the water running over the character models is pretty geniune. I'd rather go and find a better RPG that doesn't have "f*ck" used more common than another swear in some parts of Australia.

content:
r 28, 2012
												Having never played the Games Of Thrones RPG before I was pleasantly surprised by Of Orcs And Men. It's a linear RPG where you control an orc and a goblin. The goblin is good for debuffing and silently killing off enemies and the orc can be used for mob control basically. There's also a tag team move where you can throw away the goblin and inflict massive damage. The camps you visit will act as a hub for your quests.That doesn't sound all that exciting, right ? It's not, really. But the combat mechanic is somewhat fresh. During combat you can pause the game and choose your actions. Yes, we've seen it before. But maybe it's because of the characters; they're exact opposites of each other and that's what makes it so fun to play.Let's see, what else... the game can be finished in approximately 12-15 hours. The graphics are amazing; the whole things runs at a solid 60FPS. The voice acting is quite alright and the music is very good.[Rating: 85/100]Recommended ! (character limits suck !)

												Absolutely gutted.I will start by saying that i only gave this game half an hour or so if that. I thought "wow, an orc driven game!" which got me going right away as i love the greenskin races. everything i'd seen including artwork, trailers and so on pointed to it being a fantastic game full of action and freedom to experience the lush, rich world that the creators so painstaikingly created. the pros: it is a beautifully animated game, well voiced and intriguing from the first minute. the two main characters are deep and interesting. it made me want from minute one to explore and play this game, (right up until the combat that is.) the musical score is amazing, that much that i bought it for my roleplaying group games. The cons: The downside of this game comes in the disappointing gameplay. it is done in the same format of SWTOR and dragon age which i find a bit annoying anyway, preferring the feeling of fully controlling the character. the switching between two characters isn't in my opinion very well done, and i found myself fighting to keep both alive instead of accomplishing team maouvers etc. the games pace in general isnt very fast, and it feels like a game in its development stage still. it is also criminally restrictive, railroading you which is even worse as the game looks beautiful but there is very little interaction.at best, a 6/10 simply for the idea and the music. the game is not good at all. It's so bad i feel like it was a complete waste of £20.
