content:
y 19, 2014
												I've had Of Orcs And Men on my wishlist since it's release. The premise sounded very interesting and the idea of playing as an Orc for once made it even better. However, I held off on purchasing the game. I know Focus does not always release the best of games and I usually give them some time to get all the bugs and stuff under control before I purchase any of their titles. I also saw the critic scores that were just mediocre, but I don't always agree with critics. I said all that to say I have been waiting to play this game for quite a while now and was eager and convienced I would enjoy it. The story is pretty good. The dialouge options are really nice. It's great to hear your character actually say your dialouge choices instead of the silent avatar syndrome. Combat is meh. It's exactly the same as Game of Thrones. It's a mix of real-time/Turn-based combat that has you switching your attention between controlled characters. The problem I have with combat in Of Orcs And Men is the same problem I had in Game of Thrones. All encounters seem to have a slim margin of victory. You will focus on one characters attacks and after issuing 2 or 3 skills, you'll notice the other character is about to die. I don't understand how both of my characters seem to always be near death everytime I change focus. As well the skills you choose in combat aren't all that varied and I found myself sticking to a one two punch combo with my Orc and leaving the goblin as fodder since he's worthless in combat.Combat can be forgive though. I don't mind a challenge as long as the story is good. The reason I do not recommend Of Orcs And Men is FOV!!! That's right! The field of view for this game has to be about 30. Your Orc takes up 45% of the screen. If you choose to switch to the Goblin you're presented with a super zoomed in view. The graphics are great, the set pieces are nice, why they chose to make the view so damn limited and not show off their work defies logic. Game of Thrones had the same issue, but there was a work around. This game has none. It feels like you're trying to play a game while wearing your creepy uncle's coke bottle glasses. I got so dizzy that, after only 1 hour of play I had to stop. I felt like I was going to throw up. Even 30 minutes after playing the game I still feel slightly dizzy. Of Orcs And Men has to worst FOV I have ever experienced in a game.  I doubt I will ever play another Focus release again.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 21, 2015
												There are many points "for" this game.  But here are the main reasons why I choose to thumbs down this game.  First, the field of view is truly annoying.  For a 3rd person game, one has to rely on moving the mouse too much.  Second, the clunky "que" system to fight.  Each character has up to 4 slots to que up an action.  Even though through the course of this game I did get used to it...it is still a really terrible way for actions to be given.  Third, you have two characters.  One is for stealth and assassination the other is a fighting "tank".  ALL situations are perfect for the fighter.  Not all situations are perfect for the assassin.  Why?  Seriously!  Why?  If you are going to have two characters to control give them both an equal amount of situations where their skills are perfect.  I can't even begin to relate how many times I snuck up on a group of enemies only to find out I can't assassinate anyone because of the way they were placed.  Why even give that option to the players then?  Thirdly, there isn't a lot of loot and there is ZERO gold.  Want to upgrade?  Want to get new weapons or armour?  You need "trade points".  You get trade points with the scant few random chests that only contain ONE item or are given a couple here and there by the game.  None of the items end up being all that great even with the "upgrades".  It is hard to tell the difference between one item to the next.  They all feel basically the same in the long run.  Fourth, and last (just to keep it short)...  There are a LOT of cutscenes in this game.  Most you can skip over.  The ones for the last battle YOU CANNOT SKIP!  Imagine this...  You are fighting the last battle and die.  When you begin again you realise not only do you have to fight two battles until you get to the last battle but you have to watch the cutscenes!  You CANNOT SKIP THEM!  THEY ARE ALSO LONG CUTSCENES!  That's right.  The makers of this game give a BIG "F-You!" to the players with a three battle and two cutscene ending where you cannot skip the cutscenes.  True, you there are segments where you can "fastforward" but the cutscenes still last MINUTES.  You might think, "Minutes aren't that bad..."  But when I am able to get up, walk to my kitchen, get a drink, come back and I still have a long time to wait...  THAT is too long.  THAT is the epitomy of annoying and unneccissary.The end battle is winnable.  The unskippable end battle cutscenes WILL make you rage-quit so you will never win it.My two cents?  Save yourself the aggravation and frustration and pass on this game.  If they EVER fix it so you can skip the end battle cutscenes then yes, by all means get it.  But I doubt they will ever do that so pass on this one.

content:
ry 22, 2014
												Purely from a writing standpoint, this is one of the most overlooked gems in the RPG genre. If you love story driven RPGs, I highly suggest considering this game. Tons of games talk about "Mature Themes" but this one really hits that nail on the head, and not just from the adult language (which there's a lot of). It covers racism, slavery, political ambition, violence, and betrayal. I felt both of the main characters were well written and it was interesting to see how their interactions with each other evolved as the story progressed.Now onto the actual game systems.The combat system isn't going to be everyone's cup of tea. It's just like Game of Thrones, super slow mow where you can queue up 4 moves for each character. If you haven't played GoT, it's like KOTOR but without the actual pause. Difficulty of combat spikes a bit too and can be pretty hard when you don't get assassinations done before hand.The game is really linear and there's almost no exploration. There's a handful of side quests but, they need to be done right then and there. Maps are very railroady with minimal hallway detours to find an occasional goody.Each hero has 2 full trees and another tree split in half to work together/class specialty. It's by no means one of the most flexible systems in the genre but, it is far better than many others.Game also isn't a huge, 40+ hour epic. I would expect 10-25 hours depending on difficulty with combat.

content:
6, 2013
												I just finished "Of Orcs and Men." I really enjoyed this console ARPG in its PC form with a gamepad. It has nice visuals, sound and music as well as a very good story with likable dual protagonists, both of whom you control throughout the adventure. The combat system which goes into slow motion when you hit a button to begin selecting up to 4 attacks or abilities and returns to normal speed when you are done is fluid, involving and fun. Switching between the characters in combat is a breeze. The streamlined UI is a pleasure to use with a gamepad. The game is very light on loot but your characters are always progressing via level ups with new skills and abilities as well as loot you acquire from chests and defeated enemies. You sometimes also get loot from merchants who can (and you'll always want to do this) upgrade your armor and weapons. The game is not about constant looting of stuff though. It is about two great characters on a quest with a good story with fun combat along the way. The Orc Arkail, is a warrior and the Goblin, Styx is a rogue who is a lot of fun to use for his stealth abilities at times. I found it best to develop Arkail as a tank and Styx as melee DPS but you can give focus to DPS on Arkail and ranged DPS on Styx if you prefer. I give it a 8 out of 10 and feel the game was underrated by professional reviews and some PC gamers alike who I think didn't give it a fair chance based on it not being a "PC game" but rather a console game ported to PC. It is a good solid port. I experienced no problems with it. Steam tells me I played it for 29 hours but subtracting out snacks, etc. I think it was probably more like 25 or 26 hours roughly and I took all side quests and checked everywhere for chests as I went along.

content:
, 2014
												I begin by saying Of Orcs and Men won't be for everyone. In fact I recommend this game only to fans of the tactical-RPG genre, as even action-RPG fans may be spurned. Combat is slower and more strategic then most hack and slashes (stealth can be the key factor of progression). The skill trees (or should I say circles) require a great deal of attention as they can become crucial in fights. This game does a lot of things right, but it's challenge requires perseverance. Graphics and story are top notch like most RPGs, however choice never seemed to play a real role outside of differing cutscenes/achievments. I also would've liked a stronger economy and more inventory options. If you plan to tackle this one I recommend buying it on sale that way you won't be too disappointed should you not enjoy.

												Don't be fooled by this game's screenshots and video trailers. This game is an RPG at heart. The combat isn't an action hack & slash game like DMC, it's more a hardcore RPG like Dragon Age Origins but instead of being a top-down perspective, it's over the shoulder and you control two characters that you can swap to at any moment.This game's reviews may be bad but it's not really a bad game, while the voice acting doesn't match the mouth movements and the animation is pretty stiff, it's still a good game at heart. With an interesting story and some great RPG elements to keep you going.+ A lot of fun+ Great RPG+ unique and original story+ Styx is awesome+ A lot of action to be had+ Satisfying ending.- Arkail is a character that leaves more to be desired- Animations are stiff- Stealth is decent at best- Difficulty curve shoots straight up at the final half of the fifth (final) chapter

												Fantastic story! Beautiful world! Game play sucks! The line up attacks combat style, and control of two characters in combat was tedious and boring! The Goblin dies if you blink, and the Orc will rage taking control (at which point he kills the goblin) unless you constantly burn turns to calm him down. If you do take the time to calm the Orc expect to get roped every time you do so. By the end of the game I was picking rage inducing attacks to get it over with, and just playing the Goblin through combat as support for a bot that gets stuck on corners. Once the Orc rages it is just as likely to turn, and attack the Goblin so combat becomes "Hit and run the puck away!" The actual game play is just move, and fight. It's a "hack and slash" without any real control of the "hacking and slashing". The stealth play is like a bad joke as the enemies can only see the stealthed Goblin if its sucking their bick, or skull pucking the guy next to them. Linear  levels, and bad game play aside. I really enjoyed it! But with out levels and game play your just watching a bad CG cartoon with a good story. I fill the game makers could do better, and look forward to the prequel Styx:Master of Shadows.

content:
ber 13, 2014
												Pretty decent game. The artwork and environments are beautiful, but level design doesn't seem too well thought out. There's a lot of walking down hallways without much to do lacking even character dialogue to entertain you.Combat is very good. I really enjoyed the different skills that were available and the strategy that came into play in most battles. And you have to employ the strategic menu during battles or you will fail.Which is where combat was annoying. Most of the difficult battles occure immediately after a long cutscene which means if you die (and you very likely will again, and again, and again) you have to go through the cutscene (again and again and again). You can skip by pressing Esc repeatedly, but it's just incredibly frustrating. Also, the battles aren't very well balanced. I breezed through most of the game on easy so that I could enjoy the story, but then cam across maybe 3 battles that took me forever to get through. I almost just quit the game and gave up it was that frustrating.Anyway, voice acting was good and engaging but the script seemed quite stilted at points. The characters swore a lot, which I don't mind, it just seemed overdone to me and came across as the writers using swear words more as a publicity stunt rather than for dramatic emphasis. Maybe that's just me.The storyline and characters were great. Kept me interested for the duration of the game and I really enjoyed watching how the main two characters developed and got to know eachother as the game progressed.AI was a little messed up (which was also frustrating). If you ever leave one of the characters to do their own thing for a bit during combat, they are bound to do something stupid, like target the guy furthest away so they run past every other enemy and get killed on the way. Or sometimes they'll just stand there and you can't tell why. You've given them commands to carry out, you're pretty sure they haven't been stunned, but they're not responding to anything.Also, the still warm corspe of a soliders friend is apparently an everyday sight, cause they won't do anything about it. You can kill 10 people and then watch a patrol just walk over their bodies and go on their way without raising an alarm or even breaking stride. Not a game breaker, but weird for a modern game. It does make stealth assassinations a piece of cake.My recommendation. Play it on easy just for the sake of the story, otherwise the long hallways, frustrating battles and inconsistent AI aren't worth the effort.

												É um bom game, com potencial para ser ótimo, em 11 horas de jogo facilmente voce terá terminado por completo.Espero sinceramente que os desenvolvedores, continuem este projeto, uma vez que é muito interessante jogar como um goblin ou orc. Infelizmente faltou desenvolvimento neste projeto, quem sabe mais um ano de trabalho para aparar os bugs e criar uma experiencia mais ampla, o mundo é muito direcional e existem oportunidades imensas para explorar armas, ambientes e habilitades.Recomendo desde que o preco seja atraente, 25 reais está OK========================================================================It's a good game with potential to be great, 11 hours in game easily you will have completely finished.I hope that developers continue this project since it is very interesting to play as a goblin or orc. Sadly missed this development project, maybe another year working to trim the bugs and create a broader experience, the world is very directional and there are plenty of opportunities to explore weapons, environments and abilities.Recommend since the price is attractive, real 12 dollars is OK

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
r 6, 2014
												The story is tight, well paced (for the most part), and interesting: I've killed thousands of orcs and goblins over the years, and so it was fun to play as two of the "bad guys" on a mission to kill the human emperor.  The main characters are well written (despite the unnecessary profanity) and their reluctant team dynamic is fun.  The gameplay is the best part: building out both characters into the rolls I chose for them (it's clear there are several viable combinations of builds) was satisfying.  Neither character can succeed on its own so designing and implementing a team strategy was rewarding, and the challenge on normal was just right.  Each encounter felt like a discrete combat puzzle, and so I didn't mind that the levels were, almost without exception, linear pathways from one encounter to the next because I looked forward to the next encounter.  The graphics do the job: sometimes pretty, sometimes ugly, usually just fine.  The music is sparse, but has character.  The supporting cast is, for the most part, poorly acted, which is the only truly disappointing aspect of the game.In sum, if you want a combat focused RPG with two likable characters and an interesting story, and can excuse the small budget presentation, this game is definitely worth the 12-15 hours it takes to finish.

content:
er 27, 2014
												This is a game where you control a hulking orc and a cunning goblin. The combat is real-time with a pause function, and requires tactical thinking and basically no reflexes, which is a valid design choice. It has RPG elements, and the world it is set in is very grim, with human fanatics having enslaved or exterminated most of your race.I don't understand the lukewarm reception this game got. It has a unique twist on the dumb old Humans vs. Orcs cliche, and both main characters are interesting and compelling. The combat, at least at the higher difficulties, requires a lot of strategic thought and good planning, and it is just so sweet to see Arkhail break the back of the last imperial soldier at the end of a long fight. On top of everything else, the game looks incredible even on the lower graphics settings. What's not to love?!

content:
r 11, 2014
												I can't recommend this game, which is a shame, because the concept is excellent. I was compelled to buy Of Orcs & Men by the idea of your typical fantasy setting being inverted to the point where the orcs are the heroes and the humans are the barbaric oppressors/invaders. Unfortunately, the game tries WAY too hard to be funny, edgy, and gritty when all it really needed to do was be epic in the literal sense. I don't typically mind profanity, but the dialogue is so frought with cursing, sexual innuendo, and poor attempts at wit that it alternates between feeling forced and being downright juvenile. When it isn't being juvenile, the game is constantly going out of its way to remind you that this is the F--king GRIMDARK, and everything sucks. The humans are EVIL, man. The orcs are BADASS, dude. Essentially, everything in this game seems to be a charicature with little in the way of depth. This is extremely unfortunate given the incredible potential of the setting. Less than an hour in, and I just can't play anymore. I really want to like this game, but I've seen enough. I might be willing to soldier on and hope that the dialogue and plot/character development improve, but the controls and gameplay also leave quite a bit to be desired. At the end of the day, this game just wasn't for me. There may be someone out there that would enjoy Of Orcs & Men...but I can't imagine them being older than twelve.

												I've tried to play this game on several different occasions and I just CAN'T get behind these controls! In my opinion, this was the wierdest control scheme in a game; EVER! Secondly, I never felt like I was in control of my character. You assign something for them to do, then they do it; while you wait and watch. Well, it's pretty quick, but you still don't feel in control. It's almost turn-based but not quite, almost real-time but not quite...I wish it would make up it's mind, because whatever it is; it doesn't work. That is to say, for ME it doesn't work. So, in truth, I cannot recommend this game. I picked it up on sale, so I didn't lose much, but that's not the point. I really, REALLY wanted to play this and enjoy it. I thought it was a great story idea, great concept. Good visuals too, but at the end of the day, it doesn't matter how good it looks if it's not fun to play. So, no. don't waste your time OR money, it's just not worth it.

content:
29, 2016
												Wha- who- how the... I've never encountered a game that in almost every way was good. Thoroughly enjoyable, all features at the very least adequate. All except one, that one bad feature completely, utterly destroys the game. That combat system... just... who the bloody hell saw that, played that and thought "yep, that's a functional and enjoyable way to play the game. Let's ship it"?!  The combat system works like this, LB and RB each bring up a radial menu with either offensive or defensive attacks. Key phrase there; "defensive attacks". Even your defence is just a slightly quicker offence. There doesn't seem to be a way to block or dodge anything. It works by giving the two characters orders like a turn-based strategy game but in realtime. Well it slows down time when you open the attack menus but you have so little control over the characters actions during a fight. It clearly should've been a hack'n'slash affair. Everything else about it was alright.I've played this for about two hours, a bit of it was offline. I've also played Styx and that had some issues with combat but by God it's infinitely better than this.

content:
19, 2014
												isnt ♥♥♥♥ just a wonderful word. ♥♥♥♥. ♥♥♥♥. ♥♥♥♥. ♥♥♥♥.FUUUUUUUCK."♥♥♥♥," is essentially the whole game's dialouge. Nothing but pointless and repetitive swearing. I understand the premise and in war swearing is commonplace; that whole swearing like a sailor metaphor rings a bell. Although I WISH they would swear like a sailor, it would at least be more colorful. Every two minutes its, "look at me I said the word ♥♥♥♥." Yes, ♥♥♥♥ is a versitile word but there are a variety of other swear words that can be used to articulate communications between characters. And dont give me the crap about how "theyre dumb, theyre orcs and only know how to kill." The first scene shows complex communication and articulation, Its a very wierd disconnect to go from "Oh, why thank you. Look at my manners, arent I so polite," to "♥♥♥♥. Me swing ♥♥♥♥ing sword. You bleed all over ♥♥♥♥ing ground," (not actual quotes). Was the script proof read by a 13 year old who just discovered he can swear among friends?Oh right this is a game. WHY DO I HAVE TO MICRO MANAGE EVERYTHING? I undestand the game developer probably didnt want another hack and slash game but this is not the way to do it, Im just hacking and slashing really slow. I also understand that other games have done this sort of mocromanaging well such as dragon age: origins.The way this game's comabt works is that you have to issue commands on the fly in a slowed down period which essentially pauses the fight every 20 seconds. Lets return to DA:O, you created a preset queue of attacks to perform based on certian battle conditions with respect to the individual character's skills and abilities. Because its all preset the combat happens a lot faster and creates more complex combat scenarios. In DA:O you can interupt individual characters from performing their attack queues (or even quickly switch to a different preset queue) to issue specific commands to address a unique battle situation. In Orcs and Men, you dont get that tactical experience, the attack queue is created on the spot and then terminated, repeating every few seconds. This would be a thousand times more bareable if I could issue my character to auto attack when I dont have attcks in the queue.Although, I do like the slow down aspect of the battle rather than a complete pause because that forces the player to act and not just sit there and figure out every small detail.

r 4, 2014
												While it does look nice and has decent voice acting, the camera often gets in the way. The core gameplay is battle heavy,  and relies on you selecting skills to use in a Baldur's Gate/Dragon Age kind of way, which is awkward since the rest of the game sets it up to be a third-person beat 'em up. Since you have to pick every skill by hand (or set up to 9 to a hotkey), each battle wears on your nerves. On harder difficulties, it's not clear what tactic to use against who, basically making you use all of the skills and hope something sticks. Of Orcs and Men tries, but doesn't quite get its main aspects right. And that makes it quite a disappointment.

												At first you think it's a basic RPG, with leveling, party members, and an engaging storyline. Ehhh... not really.The game looks good. The lighting, effects, models, everything graphics wise looks good. The sounds and music are well put together. The plot isn't all that bad either. Fantasy creatures (orcs) are being hunted down by humans. Nothing completely original, but it's interesting. The combat system, while annoying at times, isn't really all that bad. It plays like KotOR did, where you select abilities and watch it play through, stopping to add more in the queue. But RPG's are all about the story. You want to know more about the characters and the world they live in. This game rushes through all that. Every now and again they give you a pretty good scene, but it is still bogged down in all the pointless stuff from before. It had something, but it just couldn't deliver on where it counted.

content:
r 4, 2014
												Criminally underrated RPG, but then I can't say it's for everyone.What I loved: The story, the setting, the character interaction. It has a very captivating world with a pretty good mythology, and the two main characters are among the most memorable in any recent game I've played. The relationship between Arkhail and Styx feels very genuine —you really get to care about those two.The downside: The combat system is quite a bit loose, the AI is stupid. The combat mechanics consist in pausing, choosing targets, queueing attacks and abilities, and constantly switching between Arkhail and Styx, making sure their actions complement each other. It works for the most part but it's not very refined and you can bump into some pretty frustrating moments as a result. The way certain fights are designed doesn't help too much either, and if you leave the AI to make its own decisions (by only focusing on one character, that is), you'll be screwed most of the time. It's far from being unplayable, but I can see these problems turning off a lot of people.It's a flawed game, but a very charming one. Recommended if you think you can get past the somewhat flimsy combat and you don't mind its linear, basic design.

content:
8, 2015
												Of Orcs and Men is, at its core, a tactical RPG about the interesting symbiosis between a rogue and a warrior in a fantasy RPG.  The warrior has a stun attack with a high chance of being dodged.  The rogue has an attack which prevents the target from dodging for 5 seconds.  Put them together and you feel clever!  This gameplay works, and we've seen it work in other games.  For example, the original Dragon Age had the exact same symbiosis between a rogue and a warrior and it worked great there.  However....This is a negative review, but I'll start with the good:+ Very glad to see some variety in story.  The greenskins as protagonists is an interesting angle.  The story itself is mostly good.+ Graphics are decent.+ Combat has enough depth to be interesting, with lots of abilities which synnergize with each other to produce new effects.The bad:- The voice actors sound like they're muddling through lines in a second language.  Worse, it sounds like several of the lines are translated literally from the original french, meaning clever local idioms just become nonsense.- Game was obviously written solely with an xbox controller in mind.  When you reach a hill and have to move your mouse back to look 'up', you have to pull it about three mousepadlengths because the Y coordinate has a different sensativity than the X coordinate.  This cannot be changed in the options.-Combat is a miserable, stumbling affair.  This is the killer.  If you're skimming, read this part.As I mentioned above, the whole game is about doing clever things with your rogue and warrior TOGETHER.  So you'd assume that, generally, they target the same enemy, right?  Wrong.  Their autotargetting ALWAYS chooses different enemies, so I'm being totally serious when I say 50% of my game time was simply smashing the Q and E keys paging through interminable lists of targets trying to get them to both hit the same guy.  This would be less of a problem if the click selection works, but it doesn't.  The camera is locked 2 feet from the action, usually staring at a wall, and clicking an enemy is just as likely to select the guy 20 meters behind him as it is to select him.This is a game about combat in which I like everything except the combat.  The combat is awful.  Can not recommend.

content:
er 9, 2014
												I wanted to love this game, and it has a great deal of potential, however, this team has a serious game breaking controller issue.  The controls are a jumbled mess.  Even with autodetect on a Windows 8.1 system, a licensed and perfectly mapped Xbox 360 controller, and a ton of attempts to adjust the controller settings in the game, it is impossible to engineer a fix for this problem on the user side.  I never really got to play the actual game.  I have no save data, no progress, and no controls to use.  I essentially just idly pranced around and tried to open the menu, which was oddly mapped to L3, until I got stuck again.  In fact, the only 2 inputs that were properly mapped were lateral movement and back (left / right on the d-pad and B).  That's literally all that worked properly with the controls.I honestly would like a refund for being issued an unplayable game, but I'm not likely to receive one.  The devs won't even acknowledge there's a problem with the PC version of the game.  I believe Steam should pull this game down until the developers acknowledge and fix the problem.  My controller works perfectly fine with all other controller supporting games I own.

content:
er 12, 2014
												This game is a tricky one.Pros:+Very nice storyline (Main reason to buy this game)+Two nice skilltrees+Decent graphics+Nice sounds+No bugsCons:-GameplayI open the gameplay problem a bit.Think about classic RTS where you look on your characters from the sky, pause the game, give orders and watch the fun from the above. Goood.Now, in Of Orcs and Men you do the same. The problem is that you play in over-the-shoulder view and you control characters with WASD. It gives you the feeling that you should be able to do some real-time fighting.The fact that your characters can't really do anything on their own, means you have to control all of their moves using slow-motion, in order to survive. So you can't really do real-time fighting.That's biggest thing that bugged me throught the whole game and it made the gameplay not-so-enjoyable..

content:
, 2016
Product received for free
												Do you wanna know why I have the gall to write a review after playing it for 6 minutes?COMBAT SYSTEM > It's really-really-really bad.The combat runs in realtime, whenever you open up a list of available commands time slows a little bit, I suspect they do this to adds suspense during your decision making process. However, what actually happened was a very boring, very unresponsive combat. What you're doing is basically input commands into queue and wait for the commands to come up the top of the queue and see your character execute it in a very boring way (animation-wise). It's just.. really bad. An RPG lives and breath through the combat system. It's what makes or breaks the game. It's not the story, not the graphic, not the music, no. It's the combat system. Why? Because you're going to spend a lot of your time fighting that's why.and my experience from the first two encounter was so horrible that I decided to drop this game and uninstalled. If I didn't get this game for free I would've refund it.

content:
ber 15, 2016
												Ive had my eye on this game for quite some time, and finally decided to grab it, as well as Styx:Master of Shadow(Update: I do not recommend Styx:Master of Shadow)..  Man am I sorry i waited so long! It appeared to be more of an action type game, until i looked closer, and realized it had real time with pause combat.. Similar to Dragon Age:Origins, its also got radial ability wheels.. You control 2 characters.. The first Arkail, the mountainous, hulking Orc Berserker, who doubles as a tank.. Then Styx, the tiny comic, assassin, who doubles as a ranged damager.. Each has 2, to 2.5 Ability wheels, depending on how you spec them out..You purchase and upgrade several abilitiesa in each stance, and something else i wont spoil..Combat was very strange at first, as theres very little advanced tutorial or guide to figure out what the color of the rings on enemies mean, what certain status mean, etc.. I do NOT suggest using a controller, though completely possible i found targetting, and combat to be difficult, and far mroe precise with the m+kb.. Minus the "Tactics", its every bit that DA:O was!The sound was good.. The music was fitting for every aspect be it combat, strolling, conversation, etc.. Heavy attacks have a satisfying thud, and voices were very well done.. Especially when you consider that its Orc, and Goblin speech.. Lip syncing was pretty bad though..Graphics were servicable, but did their job.. the character models, and their gear were very detailed, but textures, and environment were less so.. It did not take away from the experience.. And thats coming from someone who places graphics high on my requirements list.. The maps constantly changed, and it never got old, as you were constantl;y moving to new locations.. Forests, snowy mountains, ghettos, island, etc.. Very good..Enemy AI were not stupid, but nothing astounding either, which is what i expected from a game on a budget.. Its better than many games.. They seem to follow the rules of aggro, and basically play their role.. Crossbowmen will thankfully switch to melee, rather tyhan standing there stupidly taking clubs to the face. Each enemy requires different types of damage to be taken down effectively.. Light, medium, and heavy attacks.. Armor piercing, poisons, destabalizing, stuns, etc.. They also have armor, and damage values..And finally, the reason thsi game shines... The story.. I was very, VERY pleasantly surprised by the story.. Where there are still cliche moments (and how can there not be this day in age.. Everythings been done) it was very good.. Twists, betrayal, choice, and consequence, trust, and more.. Its told from the view of the Orcs, who are being driven to extinction, and  put to slavery by humans.. Goblins are little more than critters, and are treated as rats.. They are mindless killing machines, who cannot speak, or have any advanced thought..Or can they? Humans are using Orcs to build massive towers, and teh Emperor is takign more and more land.. hes going to try and allign the human race with the elves, and dwarves to finish off the "greenskins".. You, the last of your tribe, The Butcher, are sent to kill the emperor before this happens.. You will need a guides to get you past the tower walls.. Enter Styx..I wont go any further, as it could spoil some things.. Everything mentioned about story is told to the polayer in the opening scene of the game, and probably in the game description tbh..  Bottom line, its n excellent game, and one you can replay, with different styles, and choices.. At first the combat may be confusing, or atleast some of the mechanics, but this only lasts a few minutes, and i was able to figure out the details quickly.. Do yourself a favor, and pick this one up.. Even at full price i would recommend it, but i was able to get it on sale for about $5.. I anxiously await a sequel!  With extremely linear levels, and playing on Normal, the campaign took me 20.5hrs, and i loved every minute!Edit: Sorry for the poor format.. Ive rewritten this 3 different times, and Steam seems to be suffering from something with the Review system,.. It wont post, or acts as if it has, and when returning, the review does not exist.. After my 3rd attempt this week, i just wanted it done, as its a great game!

content:
2013
												This game could have been much better.At first I was excited at the sights of a game which focused on the Greenskins as the protagonists rather than the usual bad guys, but after having played through the game I'm kinda stuck in the middle.The game is really story-driven because other than the story it doesn't really perform well on other aspects. Gameplay is very linear aside from a few optional side-quests which really do not matter most of the time. Choices don't really have an impact on the story and parts of the level design would make one wonder why it's even there in the first place. The graphics are alright at best but the combat leaves much to be desired - targeting can be a pain at times and the reset of skills on an enemy's death is rather annoying to say the least.If it wasn't for my love for the Greenskins, I probably wouldn't have bothered with this. The story in itself (which is supposed to be it's strong part) was rather plain and predictable. If anything I would say the best part of this game is it's amazing soundtrack. If I didn't know any better I'd say the combat music is what has driven me to finish the game.All in all.. I guess it can be considered enjoyable if you're really into Greenskins like me. Otherwise I wouldn't bother.. Glad to have picked it up on a sale because it's not worth the full retail price.

content:
15, 2016
												Eh, it's ok.  Not great, but maybe see if you can get it on sale for cheap.This is an adventure RPG.  You follow a linear set path, deal with enemies a few at a time, find some hidden treasures, change and upgrade your armor and weapons, and gain experience points from combat to level up your skills.  The world is a "fantasy" setting where the humans have come together and formed an empire after a long war against the Orcs.  Now the emperor is running a campaign of genocide against anything with green skin.  The dwarves and elves have joined him, mostly out of fear for their own people.In this game, you play as two characters.  You can switch control from one to the other on the fly, but whichever one you are NOT controlling will be active with AI control.  The AI is stupid as a bag of rocks, by the way.  The big orc is loud and likes to hit people in the face.  He has a mission:  to save his species from genocide by assassinating the human emperor.  The little goblin is tasked with helping the orc get through the city so he can do the deed.  The little goblin is very sneaky; if he enters stealth mode then the big guy will stop following you and wait until you exit stealth mode before he runs to catch up.  While in stealth mode, many times you can make a fight easier - or avoid a fight completely - by sneaking behind the enemy and assassinating them one at a time.  If a fight does break out because you are witnessed killing a soldier, then you will be alternating control between the two.  You can set a chain of commands for each of them, but they can only remember four commands at once.  Each character has his own upgrade tree, for which you gain points when you level-up.  There is one area that has SHARED commands for both of them, and each character has two fighting styles to upgrade.  The goblin has a path for ranged attacks (dagger toss) and another path for up-close fighting.  The orc has a path for strong but slow attacks, and another for attacks that allow him to also block or parry incoming blows.The graphics are pretty well done.  The music isn't awful, but also not great.  The story is interesting because it is rare that you get to play as a "bad guy" but still have it feel like you're doing the right thing.  The combat, in my opinion, is pretty terrible though.  And the path you are allowed to follow is extremely limited.  That does detract from the fun story aspects a bit, so I only give this one a rating of "Eh, it's ok" whereas if the combat system had been done a little better I might actually call it a good game.Story:  good stuff.Combat:  terrible, though the stealth assassination style is amusing for a little while.Still worth playing?  Sure, if you can get it for just a few bucks.  Don't shell out big money for this one though.If you try this one and enjoy it, consider another game in the series:  "Styx: Master of Shadows" which as of writing this I still have not played.

content:
7, 2016
												Of Orcs and Men is a game with some interesting ideas but ultimatly fails in a whole lot more areas than it actually succeeds, which seems to be a common theme with this developer as I'm playing through their games... Anyways let's get to it shall we? Combat I've had to rewrite this section actually because originally I had a big rant about the combat here but it took way too many characters and didn't leave much room for the other stuff in this review, you can still  read it if you're interested though [pastebin.com], anyways here's the short and to the point versionThe combat is pretty bad, and playing on harder difficulties only makes it worse, you control 2 characters, a big warrior orc and a small rogue goblin, they both have unique abilites that you select from a weird wheel which slows time when it pops up as you press the space key, suffice to say it's quite clunky because the game doesn't know if it wants to be turn based or real time and it's just this really weird "strategic" combat as a resultIt's a very clunky system that feels unpolished, you can't dodge / block damage in a straightforward way, it's all up to some stats and RNG, same for your enemies blocking / countering / dodging and the stupid rage mechanic for your big orc character (I go into more detail about that on the longer version) and you're always overwhelmed in numbers which limit a lot your options since only a few skills can be upgraded to be uninterruptable because the enemies interrupt most of your other attacks by hitting youA lot of encounters devolved into me using the goblin character running around in circles to avoid enemies to revive the big orc, getting 1-2 hits with him, dying and getting revived again over and over again until everyone was dead, sometimes they got hits on the goblin aswell and if he died it got even worse by the two characters reviving each other all the time and barely getting any hits in to kill the enemies, but you have to play as only 1 character in some sections which can make things even more frustratingYou can also use stealth to 1 hit K.O dudes with your goblin before you get spotted and it's a very useful way of thinning the enemies ranks before you inevitably have to face them in "real" combat, but there are a lot of fights triggered by cutscenes or with enemy placement which you can't stealth your way out of so there's that  Exploration So yeah, safe to say I'm not really happy with the combat at all, it's pure ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t a lot of times and I haven't been frustrated like this with a game in a long time, the real kicker is that you know what you do for like 90% of the whole game? Just go through straight corridors walking very slowly as a big fat orc (or a small goblin) until you get into slightly bigger rooms with a bunch of dudes in them, kill them all, go through another corridor, get to another slightly bigger room, rinse and repeat until you get to the objective at the end of the map, for the whole game, it seriously takes its toll upon you and the first time I played this game was for around 1-2 hours, but I really thought I've been playing for the whole day, serisouly it felt like an eternity, this game's combat really grinds upon your very soul and the only real exploration is that there's maybe a slightly shorter branching corridor which leads to another big room with lots of dudes in it and some loot, or you get a sidequest from an NPC in one of the hub areas and you go through the exact same formula of going through corridors and then big rooms again Story The story while it may seem interesting at times, but it's pretty meh, there's nothing really all that special about it, I think the main thing here is that it's different in a way not many other games explore because you play as Orcs and Goblins which usually are the evil bad guys and all that, but yeah this time around the humans are evil and conquered almost all the orcs and enslaved them, you're in control of an orc named Arkail, a strong elite warrior which is part of the Bloodjaws clan on a crazy suicide mission to kill the human emperor and hopefully make things better for his kin, and also Styx, a goblin rogue type character helping him along the wayThe voice acting is a mixed bag as usual with this developer and the same can be said about the characters, some can be pretty likeable like Styx which is probably one of the reasons he's got his own game which maybe I'll try at some point and then there are your generic villains or the twist which you could see from a mile away near the endBut ultimatly the story is just that, it has a nice / different coat of paint with it's setting, I'll have to admit that's what kept me going but it's pretty average and I didn't feel any real sense of satisfaction after completing it (aside from being free from the horrifying combat maybe) and at no point I really felt invested or cared for any of the characters, the only real fun one is Styx to be quite honest, the others vary on the spectrum from fine to stereotypical trope "x" or "y" characterYou have some choices but few actually matter, a lot of it it the same whatever you choose with some differences only being like a line of dialogue, the bigger changes / minor consequences are a result of sidequests if you wish to go for those Conclusion All in all I'd have to say that while it's different it's a pretty mediocre game, you're doing the same thing for pretty much all of it i.e the "Exploration" section from this review and sadly that same thing is just not all that fun to do, maybe the story might intrigue you in some way but I wouldn't hold by breath on it, it's sad to say this because this game did have some cool potential but it just didn't come to fruition, honestly don't bother with this one, but if you REALLY want to give it a go for whatever reason at least do yoruself a favor and wait to pick it up on sale

												First let me pre-face Spider Studios is not some huge company with a million dollar budget for every video game they makeThat said I gave this game a solid 8/10I had a lot of trouble figuring out the combat system, and how to make Styx and Arkail work together, but that was only because it was actually a pretty unique fighting system, and unlike modern games every battle isn't super easy.Instead the game is actually challenging so in combat you actually have to think and work for your victory and not just spam click for satisfaction. The story: It was so dark and interesting. At first it seemed stereotypical and storybookish, but as it develops the characters become very flushed out and you have a very dark and grim world painted before you, as you are given a deeper understanding of the characters and their personal struggles, but also the significance of your quest in this gameThe graphics are pretty good, especially for when this was made!You'll have an interesting time playing around with styx and arkail as you customize both to compliment one another(otherwise you probably won't be able to beat the game lol) It had one REALLY contorversial scene(monastery part) where I, who am usually silent while playing video games, audibly shouted "WHAT THE F***?!"Look past that scene and its an amazing game worth getting!

content:
5, 2015
												Well this game was pretty unique experience. Very good story, cool main characters and great visuals. Also we are being introduced to very well done fighting mechanics. They may be clunky but, when you get used to them the combat is fun as hell. If you like tactitacal approach to combat that is. It's no hack'n'slash for sure. I don't want to say too much, for I think that even talking about some of the gameplay elements would spoil the fun. I bought this game without getting to know what kind of product that is, without reading reviews, without watching videos. I can say, I'm happy about it, because it was really fresh experience. But if you are reading this, you propobly want to know more before buying, so let's get to it.If you want it short here are pros and cons:GOOD-combat system-story-main characters-statistic based, old school RPG elements-great world design-nice graphics-harsh atmoshpere-great dynamics between two protagonists-can be really challanging-musicBAD-waaaaay too short (I finished the game within 11 hours. Pretty bad for RPG-like title)-linear (linear locations <<even if nicely designed>>, linear story <<almost never when you are given a choice, your choice matters at all>>)-starts being way less challanging in the late game-can get wearisome if you try to play it without breaks-some of the secondary characters are poorly dubbed (especially human ones)So that's it for a shot way of talking about the game.The story evolves around an orc Arkail and goblin Styx. This duo is well writen and it's fun to watch how their relations evolve through the game. So, our orcish protagonist is facing a mission: kill the racist Emperor and stop the genocide of the orcs. Styx is being introduced as his guide around the human kingdom. The first part of the game is honestly not a killa. We are moving and fighting around ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s sunken in rain and mud. Quickly we can see the differneces between the two of our protagonists, not only in their appearances or way of thinking. Arkail is a tough warrior, kind of tank i'd say. Styx on the other hand is thief-like chracter, we can use him to silently eliminate some of the enemies before the real fight. After that he can stun or damage armor of the enemies to help Arkail deal bigger damage, and also make his own attakcs more deadly.After getting through the first parts of the game (that is after getting beyond the Wall) we change monotonous environment and story gets more dynamic. We are constantly hearing some funny talk between Styx and Arkail, which is nice, because game amtosphere does not feel so inflated. I must say, that if you're a fan of looting, you will be disappointed. There is not that much of equipment to choose from, although i never felt bad because of that, it was just the right amount.From technincal point of view it's well made product. Sound-wise the game is really great. Especially soundtrack which is kinda unique in its vibes and atmosphere. Graphicly OOAM is also nicely done. Orcish characters are looking amazing, human ones on the other hand not always. Locations are always good looking even if sometimes monotonous as I mantioned before. I didn't get across too many bugs. The most annoying problem I've encounterd was that from time to time one of our heroes, the one we weren't controlling at the moment, liked to get stuck on some obstacles (sometimes even invisible ones...).Two biggest flaws of OOAM is that it's short (11 hours, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥...) and linear. And it's being linear in both cases: story and locations. Non of your choices matter and places you visit are roads from point a to point b. Which is sad, because with that design i'd like to spend much more time sightseeing.To summarise: this game is kind of a flawed gem. It's well written, has great combat system, awesome music and great visuals. But the construction of the world (tunnel like levels) and story so short... well it hurts a little. However, despite these to thing I hade a lot of fun, and I do not regret those few euros I've spent on this game, and I recommend it. Not to everybody, because it's not a game for everybody. But, if you look for something more ambitious and not-so-dynamic (but awesome!) tactical fighting system does not scare you, "Of Orcs And Man" might be this, what you are looking for.

												When you first start this game up it will be hard to get past the odd controls (keyboard and mouse, i didn't use a controller) and after playing some of this developers other games it was a challenge to go forward.  But it turns out that this was actually an enjoyable action title with an interesting enough story.  It doesn't have the depth of many other titles in the genre and is pretty linear in nature.  The stealth is fun but limited to a single take down type.  Combat can be frustrating at first due to an unfamiliar mechanic/style but it gets manageable as time goes on.  The game starts out a bit rough until you can get a few key skills for Ark so that he can properly tank, but after that it becomes a cake walk.  Not the greatest but certainly worth a play through.  Especially if you pick it up on sale. I sat down for a few hours in a single day and beat it start to finish.

												Pros:-First game I've seen that tellls you flat out "Going berserk is the worst tactical solution you could make".-You may be wondering what place a goblin has in a game called 'Of Orcs And Men'? Well I did too, and the game gave a more than satisfying answer.-'Throw the halfling goblin' at its finest.-One of those precious few games that show you the world through the bloodthirsty, mindless, slaughter-happy monster's point of view.-Tactics. If you think you can win this game using default attacks and/or using one character as if this was a 3rd persong hack-and slash game, then you're gonna have a bad time.-Interesting fights and choices of attacks.Cons:-Equipment doesn't scale up with difficulty. I finished the game using some of the equipment from the first chapter, and I had more trade-points (money) then I could find a use for.-Repititive hand gestures (not that kind).-Stealth system is extremely primitive\simplistic. You can walk in front of enemies in broad daylight and they wouldn't notice you. As a stealth game enthusiast, that just felt so wrong for me.

content:
, 2013
												There are many mechanics that are left to be desired and there are several situations in the story line that make you wonder why the devs didn't make it a playable part of the game. That said though this game is a lot better than it gets credit for. Voice acting isn't the best ever but it's certainly passable. The main characters seem to actually have a team style relationship, which is good since you play both characters throughout the story. Level design isn't amazing, there are a lot of nooks and areas that look like they should be 100% accessible but aren't. But it's also not the worst I've seen. The game employs a stealth mechanic but there's not a way to stealth through an entire area as you play both characters at once and only one character can stealth. That doesn't mean it doesn't have it's place, it's still very useful.Overall the RPG mechanics are pretty solid. Both characters get attribute points when they level up as well as a new skill to learn or upgrade. And both characters skills play off eachothers strengths and weknesses quite well. You'll obtain gear from a few chests and sacks or at a vendor, not from combat. Items are upgradeable, but only once and have different attributes that fit a few different play styles.Combat itself is probably the most dissapointing. You'll have to que up attacks thru a combat menu for each character and watch it take place rather than have direct control yourself. But really as the game progresses the combat mechanics have a more tactical feeling and it starts to become more natural.You'll get some choices to pick through in dialogue menus, but there's only a couple that actually have any real affect in the game.I liked my playthrough of this game. The story is kind of fresh feeling, if a bit predictable at times. Gives a feeling of many intelligent species and races, rather than the typical feeling of orcs and goblins being mindless violent beings.This game is worth playing, I may even play through again some time.

content:
ry 18, 2015
												Overall, I think this game is worth playing, more for the story than the gameplay. If you're no huge orc fan (I'm not) grab it on a sale at £10 (50%) or so, if you're an orc lover, the full £20 is probably worth it to you.Good:Story is pretty good and well told, even though it's not particularly original.The main characters and more important side characters are well voiced.The graphics in the environment are good, the main characters are very good (Aside some nasty clipping on cloth)It's relatively long for a linear game, I didn't mess around too much and ended up clocking about 13 hours (Including deaths and retries, probably 10 hours)The main characters themselves are very good. They interact frequently, they have a pretty well told backstory and a few surprises to discover later in the game. There are a good few funny moments too. (Of the dark humour kind) The way shopping works is pretty neat. Instead of cash, anything you own has a certain value in barter points (Very few, like, 3 or 4 for a good chest piece) and each thing can be upgraded a single time. You can sell for the points and keep them like you would cash, but you won't earn any. (you can find a few in chests through the game)The music isn't particularly energetic or ringtone-memorable, but it fits the situation very well the entire time. Personally I liked it a lot.Neutral:The game is very linear. You get some choices here and there but they don't make all that much difference. There are some decent sidequests.The rpg elements are ok, but you'll end up just dumping most of the points into 2 stats for each character and using two or three skills on each. You get to upgrade each skill once, with 2 choices for each, which is decent.Bad:The combat seems like a good idea but ends up being pretty boring and annoyingly difficult. I ended up dropping it to easy at about the halfway point because it just became boring and you die ridiculously easily, though it has to be said it can feel rather cool to have ark tank everyone while styx deals with the rest one by one in order of threat. (tip, take out the rangers first, they won't target ark often, they stay out of range of his taunt)The stealth mechanics are too easily foiled by dogs simply detecting you, and at other times you can kill enemies who literally look around in your direction, but don't see you unless they move to completely face you.The general enemies and less important characters look pretty bad. Humans particularly.

er 10, 2015
												Overall, I have to say that this was a really good game, despite my contempt for the combat system. Pro's:- Storyline is well done- Good voiceovers (I'm usually not a huge fan of profanity as it shows a lack of creativity but the way it was done completely fit the context)- Great graphics with immersive environments- Good skill customization where decisions can make a pretty big difference but also fit differing playstyles- Awesome soundtrack, very fitting to the atmosphere and environments- Likable characters that are easy to connect withCon's:- Horrible combat system for an action based game (similar to Dragon Age Origins)     <disclaimer> I completely understand I am a bit bias in this regard but I really don't care for this type of combat system and believe it really held this game back from being excellent- Itemization lacks depth, not a whole lot in the way of gear and weaponsIn the end, I would definitely recommend this game, especially as it's usually on sale for under $10 and undoubtedly a worthy value for roughly 25 hours of entertainment (1 time through on medium settings). Even though I am not a fan of the combat system whatsoever, I still own Styx and am excited to delve into that game simply for the positive reasons mentioned above.

												I am so glad that I didn't let the negative reviews or complaints about the combat scare me away from playing this game. I absolutely love it! The combat system seems necessary for being in control of both characters at once without making it turn-based. The characters are amazing, the story is fun, and the game itself can be a bit challenging (but not enough to make you want to quit). My only problem was that I couldn't get the controller to work for this game, but after playing it I realized it would be much better to play with a mouse and keyboard anyway. In conclusion, I fell in love with this game and I think that if you give it a fair shot you will to!

content:
er 12, 2015
												Excellent.  What I hoped out of this title was exactly what I got.Pro:- Story- Music (Kind of like Apocalyptica's Master of Puppets cover)- VisualsCon:- Combat- Odd Lipsync and some strange character acting- Choices?  In a linear rpg?  Whatever gets me more EXP and lootDetails:The story is the number one reason to check this game out.  Like it says, the game is told through the perspective of the orcs.  While they are shown to be victims in the war the orcs are far from peace loving nature folk.  Humanity has broken a lot of the orcs but they are still a threat.  As many have said, Styx steals the show with his dark humor and interesting past.  There is an unnaturally large amount of swearing that feels very offputting.  Hearing an honorable orc discuss his nature themed religon only to drop the F-bomb midsentence is pretty jarring.Opposite of the great story is the rough combat.  By the end of the game combat will come easy (although if you're like me you'll have to drop the difficulty a notch for a few major battles).  With some work I think this could have gone over easier for players.Combat:I figured it out around the time where you "challenge" Fox.  Both characters have three "stances".  Red (left) for all offense and little defense.  Green (middle) for utilities like steath and throwing Styx.  Blue (right) for defending and range.  As you level up you can put skill points into new attacks from the three stances as well as upgrade them once (choose wisely!).  Typically for me I used Ark's roar that provokes the crowd to him (getting them off of Styx) followed up with his defense buff and then a series of arcing swipes (since he is taking on the group).  Styx buffs his knives with poison, then throws an amber bomb, followed up with his area of effect knife throw.  That is the beauty of this system is that you can set up a series of attacks for one character and then switch to the other to create another form of punishment.  During the late, late battles I had Styx target the pesky range and weaken enemies while Ark took on the rain of blows from the crowd.  Long and the short, if you can look past the indie roughness of certain elements and stick with the combat you will have a great time.  Now if you'll excuse me I'm going to start installing Styx: Master of Shadows.

content:
21, 2013
												Of Orcs and Men, a simple game that received a lot of very bad reviews. People complained about the combat, about the graphics, about everything. To be honest, I got it for cheap and decied to try it. If you can look behind the game, which is not THAT bad as people claim, you have a solid fun and simple backstory, a good unscrolling of events and for me, one of the best Goblins ever to grace a computer game: STYX. Honestly, for 7$ this game is worth it just to play with Styx and hear his foul-mouthed remarks and puerile retorts. Ark is good, but a bit high and mighty and Warrior Code orc, but Styx is just fun. The combat system is ok and honestly, I just played the game to keep the story going, which entertained me even into the end, with the classic twists and betrayals common to fantasy literature portrayed in the game. Give it a spin while its cheap, or wait for it to come on sale again. I spent 2 days finishing it and gladly enjoyed every minute of it.  As a tip make Styx go full Ranged and Ark full Offensive. Combat is a series of actions you spam over and over and can lead to a lot of broken spines and Ark killing Styx when he is in Berzerk mode XD. Invest early in Rez companion skills and just hack away with abandon as the story unfolds, finished in 12 hours in easy mode because all i wanted was to cruise the content and enjoy the Cinematics. Reached level 21 by the end. In retrospective all the skills I used were Styx Aoe Stun Bomb and Arks AOE swings over and over. Gear is kinda sparse so don´t sweat it too much, just upgrade your armor. All in all I would gladly buy part 2 if they ever release it. I  am a  fan of Styx and goblins in general, wish I had a Styx action figure too! Cheers!

												Join Arkail & Styx, a pair of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s, as they get ♥♥♥♥ done and try not to kill each other on the way. As you get to "know" them, you'll probably end up loving the two jerks as I did, they're kind of like a fantasy Kane & Lynch. If you're not totally gravy with a LOT of swearing, don't get this game. The script writer(s) use the F word like they got a job lot of it on sale and are trying to use it all up before it goes out of style.I read the other reviews complaints about the combat and they're right. The combat is very odd and at first really throws you off, and I will say that I started off hating it.  but after I decided this was more like a Telltale Game story focused game than the type of RPG game I'm used to, I actually ended up enjoying the combat, especially the stealth aspects. In fact, I ended up stealthing the majority of the combat and it was very satisfying, there's puzzle solving elements to it and having patience and observing patterns really pays off. You can actually hotkey your favorite moves for each character and avoid going into slow-motion tactical mode and that makes the combat feel a bit snappier. Although honestly, I ended up really likeing the combat because it gave me some thinking space to switch tactics up on the fly.The game does have some bugs and technical flaws, but made up for it overwhelmingly with the story, voice acting & overall experience. I enjoyed the heck out of it, and will probably play through it again to make some different choices. I only wish the further adventures of these two douchcanoes would hurry up and be available as I want to follow them around some more. I'll be buying the Styx games after I finish typing this review just to hang out with him a bit more.

content:
, 2013
												There are many mechanics that are left to be desired and there are several situations in the story line that make you wonder why the devs didn't make it a playable part of the game. That said though this game is a lot better than it gets credit for. Voice acting isn't the best ever but it's certainly passable. The main characters seem to actually have a team style relationship, which is good since you play both characters throughout the story. Level design isn't amazing, there are a lot of nooks and areas that look like they should be 100% accessible but aren't. But it's also not the worst I've seen. The game employs a stealth mechanic but there's not a way to stealth through an entire area as you play both characters at once and only one character can stealth. That doesn't mean it doesn't have it's place, it's still very useful.Overall the RPG mechanics are pretty solid. Both characters get attribute points when they level up as well as a new skill to learn or upgrade. And both characters skills play off eachothers strengths and weknesses quite well. You'll obtain gear from a few chests and sacks or at a vendor, not from combat. Items are upgradeable, but only once and have different attributes that fit a few different play styles.Combat itself is probably the most dissapointing. You'll have to que up attacks thru a combat menu for each character and watch it take place rather than have direct control yourself. But really as the game progresses the combat mechanics have a more tactical feeling and it starts to become more natural.You'll get some choices to pick through in dialogue menus, but there's only a couple that actually have any real affect in the game.I liked my playthrough of this game. The story is kind of fresh feeling, if a bit predictable at times. Gives a feeling of many intelligent species and races, rather than the typical feeling of orcs and goblins being mindless violent beings.This game is worth playing, I may even play through again some time.

												I was expecting a bit more of this game, especially story wise, but it wasn't disappointing.The combat system was fun enough, but nothing out of the ordinary. Once I got to know the basics of combat, I found the the game very easy to beat by selecting Normal difficulty. If you want a challenge, I would slide it to Hard or Very Hard. You can always change back the difficulty mid-game if you think it's too much.Especially if you do use Hard mode, there may be a problem: the cut scenes are nice, but they will play again if you die, as you can't save during combat. This means that if you have to repeat some combats, you will have to skip through a crapload of cutscenes to get back to the combat again - I am not exaggerating. This is the biggest flaw in the game.Replayability is relatively poor. Overall, I did like the game, and I really like the fantasy world the developpers presented us. I played Styx: Master of Shadows before I went for Of Orcs And Men, and I simply love the goblin Styx, and all his genesis. Arkail was a nice character to follow as well. It tasted good, but in the end I thought it could have been more, and better.Recommended on sale.

												This game could have been much better.At first I was excited at the sights of a game which focused on the Greenskins as the protagonists rather than the usual bad guys, but after having played through the game I'm kinda stuck in the middle.The game is really story-driven because other than the story it doesn't really perform well on other aspects. If I didn't know any better I'd say the combat music is what has driven me to finish the game.All in all.. I guess it can be considered enjoyable if you're really into Greenskins like me. Otherwise I wouldn't bother.. Glad to have picked it up on a sale because it's not worth the full retail price.

content:
7, 2016
												Of Orcs and Men is a game with some interesting ideas but ultimatly fails in a whole lot more areas than it actually succeeds, which seems to be a common theme with this developer as I'm playing through their games... Anyways let's get to it shall we? Combat I've had to rewrite this section actually because originally I had a big rant about the combat here but it took way too many characters and didn't leave much room for the other stuff in this review, you can still  read it if you're interested though [pastebin.com], anyways here's the short and to the point versionThe combat is pretty bad, and playing on harder difficulties only makes it worse, you control 2 characters, a big warrior orc and a small rogue goblin, they both have unique abilites that you select from a weird wheel which slows time when it pops up as you press the space key, suffice to say it's quite clunky because the game doesn't know if it wants to be turn based or real time and it's just this really weird "strategic" combat as a resultIt's a very clunky system that feels unpolished, you can't dodge / block damage in a straightforward way, it's all up to some stats and RNG, same for your enemies blocking / countering / dodging and the stupid rage mechanic for your big orc character (I go into more detail about that on the longer version) and you're always overwhelmed in numbers which limit a lot your options since only a few skills can be upgraded to be uninterruptable because the enemies interrupt most of your other attacks by hitting youA lot of encounters devolved into me using the goblin character running around in circles to avoid enemies to revive the big orc, getting 1-2 hits with him, dying and getting revived again over and over again until everyone was dead, sometimes they got hits on the goblin aswell and if he died it got even worse by the two characters reviving each other all the time and barely getting any hits in to kill the enemies, but you have to play as only 1 character in some sections which can make things even more frustratingYou can also use stealth to 1 hit K.O dudes with your goblin before you get spotted and it's a very useful way of thinning the enemies ranks before you inevitably have to face them in "real" combat, but there are a lot of fights triggered by cutscenes or with enemy placement which you can't stealth your way out of so there's that  Exploration So yeah, safe to say I'm not really happy with the combat at all, it's pure ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t a lot of times and I haven't been frustrated like this with a game in a long time, the real kicker is that you know what you do for like 90% of the whole game? Just go through straight corridors walking very slowly as a big fat orc (or a small goblin) until you get into slightly bigger rooms with a bunch of dudes in them, kill them all, go through another corridor, get to another slightly bigger room, rinse and repeat until you get to the objective at the end of the map, for the whole game, it seriously takes its toll upon you and the first time I played this game was for around 1-2 hours, but I really thought I've been playing for the whole day, serisouly it felt like an eternity, this game's combat really grinds upon your very soul and the only real exploration is that there's maybe a slightly shorter branching corridor which leads to another big room with lots of dudes in it and some loot, or you get a sidequest from an NPC in one of the hub areas and you go through the exact same formula of going through corridors and then big rooms again Story The story while it may seem interesting at times, but it's pretty meh, there's nothing really all that special about it, I think the main thing here is that it's different in a way not many other games explore because you play as Orcs and Goblins which usually are the evil bad guys and all that, but yeah this time around the humans are evil and conquered almost all the orcs and enslaved them, you're in control of an orc named Arkail, a strong elite warrior which is part of the Bloodjaws clan on a crazy suicide mission to kill the human emperor and hopefully make things better for his kin, and also Styx, a goblin rogue type character helping him along the wayThe voice acting is a mixed bag as usual with this developer and the same can be said about the characters, some can be pretty likeable like Styx which is probably one of the reasons he's got his own game which maybe I'll try at some point and then there are your generic villains or the twist which you could see from a mile away near the endBut ultimatly the story is just that, it has a nice / different coat of paint with it's setting, I'll have to admit that's what kept me going but it's pretty average and I didn't feel any real sense of satisfaction after completing it (aside from being free from the horrifying combat maybe) and at no point I really felt invested or cared for any of the characters, the only real fun one is Styx to be quite honest, the others vary on the spectrum from fine to stereotypical trope "x" or "y" characterYou have some choices but few actually matter, a lot of it it the same whatever you choose with some differences only being like a line of dialogue, the bigger changes / minor consequences are a result of sidequests if you wish to go for those Conclusion All in all I'd have to say that while it's different it's a pretty mediocre game, you're doing the same thing for pretty much all of it i.e the "Exploration" section from this review and sadly that same thing is just not all that fun to do, maybe the story might intrigue you in some way but I wouldn't hold by breath on it, it's sad to say this because this game did have some cool potential but it just didn't come to fruition, honestly don't bother with this one, but if you REALLY want to give it a go for whatever reason at least do yoruself a favor and wait to pick it up on sale

content:
15, 2016
												Eh, it's ok.  Not great, but maybe see if you can get it on sale for cheap.This is an adventure RPG.  You follow a linear set path, deal with enemies a few at a time, find some hidden treasures, change and upgrade your armor and weapons, and gain experience points from combat to level up your skills.  The world is a "fantasy" setting where the humans have come together and formed an empire after a long war against the Orcs.  Now the emperor is running a campaign of genocide against anything with green skin.  The dwarves and elves have joined him, mostly out of fear for their own people.In this game, you play as two characters.  You can switch control from one to the other on the fly, but whichever one you are NOT controlling will be active with AI control.  The AI is stupid as a bag of rocks, by the way.  The big orc is loud and likes to hit people in the face.  He has a mission:  to save his species from genocide by assassinating the human emperor.  The little goblin is tasked with helping the orc get through the city so he can do the deed.  The little goblin is very sneaky; if he enters stealth mode then the big guy will stop following you and wait until you exit stealth mode before he runs to catch up.  While in stealth mode, many times you can make a fight easier - or avoid a fight completely - by sneaking behind the enemy and assassinating them one at a time.  If a fight does break out because you are witnessed killing a soldier, then you will be alternating control between the two.  You can set a chain of commands for each of them, but they can only remember four commands at once.  Each character has his own upgrade tree, for which you gain points when you level-up.  There is one area that has SHARED commands for both of them, and each character has two fighting styles to upgrade.  The goblin has a path for ranged attacks (dagger toss) and another path for up-close fighting.  The orc has a path for strong but slow attacks, and another for attacks that allow him to also block or parry incoming blows.The graphics are pretty well done.  The music isn't awful, but also not great.  The story is interesting because it is rare that you get to play as a "bad guy" but still have it feel like you're doing the right thing.  The combat, in my opinion, is pretty terrible though.  And the path you are allowed to follow is extremely limited.  That does detract from the fun story aspects a bit, so I only give this one a rating of "Eh, it's ok" whereas if the combat system had been done a little better I might actually call it a good game.Story:  good stuff.Combat:  terrible, though the stealth assassination style is amusing for a little while.Still worth playing?  Sure, if you can get it for just a few bucks.  Don't shell out big money for this one though.If you try this one and enjoy it, consider another game in the series:  "Styx: Master of Shadows" which as of writing this I still have not played.

												Took about 15 hours to beat on Medium, I recommend this game. Good humor, good game (it seems they may have had a bit of a budget issue but it doesn't show much), and the gameplay is good. As others have mentioned here the combat involves picking different moves from a skill wheel, with no cool downs (some of Styx's moves require Concentration though). Styx Master of Shadows is a prequel to this game, which I also recommend. As for order of playing them I think either one could be played first, I don't think anything would be spoiled playing one before the other.Overall it feels unique, and I may play it again sometime to pick different dialogue options or try different builds.
